headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q4 2015 Staples, Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Joyce and I will be the operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I wou
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q4 2015 Staples, Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Joyce and I will be the operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
I would now like to turn the call over to your host for today, Chris Powers, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joyce. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us for our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. During today's call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP metrics. Please see the Financial Measures and Other Data section of the Investor Informati
componenttext:
Thanks, Joyce. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us for our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. 
During today's call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP metrics. Please see the Financial Measures and Other Data section of the Investor Information portion of Staples.com for a reconciliation of these measures. Certain information we will discuss constitutes forward-looking statements for the purposes of the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by such forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including those discussed or referenced in Staples' 10-K, filed this morning. 
Here to discuss Staples' Q4 performance and outlook are Ron Sargent, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Christine Komola, Chief Financial Officer. Also joining us are Shira Goodman, President, North American Operations; and John Wilson, President of International Operations and Head of Global Transformation. 
Ron?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Chris, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. This morning, we announced our Q4 results. Total company sales declined 2% year-over-year, excluding the impact of store closures and changes in foreign exchange rates. Non-GAA
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Chris, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. This morning, we announced our Q4 results. Total company sales declined 2% year-over-year, excluding the impact of store closures and changes in foreign exchange rates. Non-GAAP operating income rate was flat at 5.1% versus Q4 of last year, and non-GAAP earnings per share came in at $0.26. This was at the lower end of our guidance due to soft sales, and includes a headwind of about $0.02 per share from the stronger U.S. dollar. 
In 2015, our top priority was to stabilize total company sales and earnings per share after a couple of years of heavy investments to transform Staples. For the full year, sales were down less than 1% versus 2014, excluding the impact of store closures and foreign exchange. Our non-GAAP earnings per share for 2015 came in at $0.89 per share. And if you exclude a $0.04 to headwind from the stronger U.S. dollar, our non-GAAP earnings per share for the full year were down about $0.03 versus last year. 
We continue to make good progress on many of our key initiatives in Q4. We grow solid growth in categories beyond office supplies in North American contract. We improved profitability in Staples.com. We delivered strong growth in our omni-channel offering. We grew copy and print in stores and online. We grew the top line and improved portfolio Australia, New Zealand and China. We continue to right size our retail network and preserve profitability across the chain. We exceeded our 2-year goal to reduce cost by $500 million. We improved operating margin rate in our North American businesses. And we extended the Office Depot merger agreement and financing arrangements to allow for the completion of ongoing federal court litigation with the Federal Trade Commission. 
Let me give you a little more color on our fourth quarter highlights. And I'll start with North American contract, where sales were flat in local currency during the fourth quarter, we were up against our toughest comparison of the year in Q4. On a 2-year stack basis, sales grew 7% in local currency during the fourth quarter, and this was consistent with the 2-year trend we've achieved throughout 2015. Over the past few years, we've added nearly 300 specialists to drive growth in categories beyond office supplies, enhanced our contract website and introduced new digital selling tools to our sales team. We continue to benefit from those investments during the fourth quarter. We achieved double-digit growth in breakroom supplies and promotional products and high single digit growth in facility supplies. In total, contract sales in categories beyond office supplies grew in the low single-digit during the fourth quarter and now account for approximately half of our entire contract sales mix. 
Staples.com. We remain focused on balancing sales growth with profit improvement. During Q4, sales were up 1% in local currency, and operating margin rate increased by more than 100 basis points. We achieved gross margin dollars growth versus Q4 of last year. This year, we had a more targeted approach to driving profitable promotions with small business customers. We also continued to improve customer conversion on our desktop and mobile websites as a result of the investments we've made to improve the user experience. Customers continue to embrace our omni-channel offering, which grew double digits during Q4 and for the full year. In 2015, we generated nearly $0.5 billion of omni-channel sales through our in-store Staples.com kiosk as well as our click-and-collect features like Buy Online, Pick Up in Store. During the fourth quarter, we began piloting our newest omni-channel capability, Ship From Store. Ship from Store improves the customer experience. It allows us to manage our inventory more efficiently and positions us for same-day delivery. Early results are encouraging. 
Turning to copy and print. Same-store sales in North America were up in the low single-digit during the fourth quarter. Our copy and print account managers continue to drive growth with small and medium business customers. We grow strong traffic to stores for key categories like business cards and signs and banners. We also achieved solid growth in services like shredding at shipping throughout the year. Copy and print is having a growing impact on our business. Today, copy and print represents nearly 10% of our retail sales mix, and generates a gross margin rate that is well above the half [ph]. 
In Australia -- Australia, New Zealand business, we grew the top line and improved the bottom line for the third consecutive quarter. And we've built on our momentum in the China achieving strong double-digit sales growth and profitability during the fourth quarter. In North American stores, we continued to take aggressive action to right size our store networks. During Q4, we closed 12 stores, bringing our total store closures to 242 in North America over the past couple of years. We also continued to improve store productivity. Gross margin dollars per square foot were up year-over-year, and we drove operating margin rate improvement versus Q4 of last year. 
In summary, we got a lot done during the fourth quarter and the full year as we continue to transform Staples. That said, we also came up short on our goals in a few key areas and we have more work to do. In North American contract, while sales prints were stable on a 2-year stack basis, our plans call for low single-digit sales growth in Q4. The majority of the difference was driven by softer-than-expected macro trends and fewer large customer wins in beyond office supplies categories versus Q4 of last year. 
In  North American Stores & Online, customer traffic was weak during the fourth quarter. Some of this headwind was driven by our decision to be less promotional during the holiday season and not to open our stores on Thanksgiving Day. But beyond these headwinds, we continue to face weak traffic in our stores and our desktop website in the United States. In Europe, we continue to make progress restructuring the business. Unfortunately, our progress was more than offset by significant headwinds during Q4. During 2015, we've faced pressure from the negative impact of the stronger U.S. dollar on our dollar-denominated product cost. These headwinds have been most pronounced in Europe contract for many of our larger customers at fixed-price agreements that didn't allow for us to immediately pass along cost increases. During Q4, these headwinds continued and we didn't have as much success recovering the increased costs as we have planned. The bottom line in Europe was also pressured by customer disruptions from an ERP implementation in our UK contract business as well as the highly promotional retail environment during the holidays. Despite these headwinds, we did generate a profit in Europe during Q4, although our bottom line results came in below our expectations. 
Better news relates to the investments we've made reduced cost on a global basis. When we reported our third quarter results, we were on track to hit our 2-year goal of $500 million of annualized cost reductions. As a result of weaker sales in Q4, we made the decision to take out additional cost and also to streamline our organization during the quarter bringing our 2-year annualized cost reductions to approximately $550 million. 
We had a few goals in streamlining the organization. We wanted to build a simplified structure that will speed up decision making. We wanted to reduce cost, and we wanted to improve financial flexibility to pursue our critical objectives in 2016. 
During the fourth quarter, we also made leadership changes to drive these objectives and better position Staples for the future. Shira Goodman was named President North American Operations. She now has responsibility for our business-to-business, online and retail operations across the United States and Canada. John Wilson was named President of International Operations and Transformation. He now has responsibility for operations in Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Latin America and Asia, and John will also lead the company strategy and overall transformation efforts. In their new roles, Shira and John will be responsible for driving results against our 2016 company-wide objectives. We'll focus on just 3 critical priorities, and this build on our success over the past few years and they also address the areas where we've come up short of our goals. In 2016, we're completely focused on doing fewer things better. And I'm pleased to report that we expect to get back to earnings growth in 2016. 
First, we'll accelerate growth in categories beyond office supplies. These categories account for approximately $10 billion of our global sales, which is just under half of our total company sales mix. Our growth beyond office supplies will be fueled by a few key categories: planning and breakroom supplies, mail and ship supplies and services. As I mentioned a few minutes ago, we've added hundreds of specialists to drive growth beyond office supplies in our contract business over the past few years. In 2016, we plan to build on this success by adding more than 100 incremental specialists, bringing our total to more than 1,000 contract specialists focused on beyond office supplies growth. 
We'll also expand our assortment in categories beyond office supplies through Staples brand offerings. Customers trust the value and expertise of Staples branded products and core categories and also beyond office supplies categories as well. 
Our second objective is to grow our mid-market penetration in contract. There are hundreds of thousands of mid-market customers that we don't serve today. And they're spending billions of dollars a year on the products and services we sell. We're increasing our focus on customer acquisition and retention and also growing our share of wallet. In 2016, we'll increase the size of our mid-market acquisition sales force by more than 20%. We'll strengthen our value proposition with our mid-market loyalty program which is driving increased expand and greater share, higher retention rates and increased customer engagement. And we'll leverage the strength of our category specialists to drive growth in categories beyond office supplies. Historically, there has been an overlap between our Staples.com and mid-market contract businesses. Our new simplified structure will help us better serve these customers. 
And our third priority is to improve traffic, both in stores and online. Weak customer traffic was a significant hurdle for us this last year, and driving customers to our store and online is crucial to our success in 2016. In stores, we're focused on improving customer conversion, accelerating growth in our services business and building our omni-channel momentum. Online, we'll continue to sharpen our pricing, ensure that customers fully understand the value that Staples provides and expand our assortment of products and services. 
These 3 priorities for 2016 are critical for Staples to succeed either as a standalone company or combined with Office Depot. 
Before I review our segment results, let me just give you an update on the Office Depot acquisition. First of all, our commitment to the acquisition hasn't changed. Our top priority is to get the deal done. The acquisition will position us to better serve the changing needs of business customers and also allow us compete more effectively against the large and diverse set of competitors. 
During the fourth quarter, the Federal Trade Commission and the Canadian Competition Bureau challenged the acquisition. The FTC's argument is that this transaction would lead to the largest and most powerful companies in the world paying higher prices for sticky notes, pens, pencils, notepads, file folders, paper clips and copy paper. When in fact, we have publicly committed to reinvest a significant portion of the merger synergies to lower prices for all customers. 
In addition, the FTC has established an incredibly narrow market definition to fit its narrative. It is also concerned with B2B customers that spend at least $500,000 a year on just these categories, which is a tiny portion of the overall marketplace. In fact, more than 99% of our commercial customers will be unaffected by the merger even based on the FTC's narrow view of the market.  In reaching its decision, we believe that the FTC is acting against the best interest of hundreds of thousands of business customers and millions of consumers who would benefit from this acquisition. The FTC is also completely ignoring the millions of our products beyond office supplies that customers purchase from us, everything from cleaning supplies to breakroom snacks, to furniture and technology. They're also conveniently excluding ink and toner, which is one of our largest core categories from their market definition. The FTC's actions are based on a flawed and very narrow definition of the marketplace and a deep misunderstanding of the competitive landscape. Unfortunately, the FTC completely disregards and disruptive effect of stronger and larger new competitors in the digital economy. The FTC's decision also ignores the reasoning in its own unanimous approval of the Office Depot, OfficeMax merger in 2013. At that time, the FTC acknowledged that Staples and Office Depot face strong position from a host of competitors. Since 2013, competition has materially intensified, not lessened, including share gains by Amazon and other Internet players, big-box retailers, independent distributors and many others. In an effort to address the FTC's concerns, we've proposed divesting up to $1.25 billion of commercial contract business and related assets. The FTC promptly rejected our offer. Nevertheless, we continue to make progress on the acquisition. On February 2, we completed the extension of our acquisition financing arrangements and extended the merger agreement from February 4 to May 16. The extension will allow us for the completion of federal court litigation with the FTC. The preliminary junction hearing is scheduled to begin on March 21 and we expect the decision by Math 10. 
The European Commission announced on February 10 that it has approved the transaction on the condition that we divest Office Depot's European contract business and all of Office Depot's operations in Sweden. We have committed to meet these requirements, and we will also divest Office Depot's retail, online and catalog operations in Europe in connection with closing the merger. We are very pleased with the European Commission's approval. I think the acquisition has now been approved in Australia, New Zealand, China and 23 countries in Europe. Regulatory agencies around the world clearly understands the value that this transaction will bring to customers of all sizes. 
We also recently extended -- entered into an agreement with Essendant to divest more than $550 million of office products revenue and related assets, subject to the successful completion of the acquisition. The commercial business and assets being divested relate primarily to accounts where Staples and Office Depot act as wholesalers to minority and women-owned office-supply retailers. Approximately half the revenue we plan to divest to Essendant is from Fortune 500 companies, and more than 25% of the revenue is from Fortune 100 companies. 
We remain prepared to hit the ground running with our integration plans once the deal is approved. And we remain committed to our previous target of more than $1 billion of net synergies over the 3-year integration period. And as a reminder, this target is net of investments to provide increased value to our customers. 
In summary, the acquisition of Office Depot is good for customers. It's good for associates, and it's good for our shareholders. This has been a surprisingly long and frustrating road, and we look forward to a full and fair judicial review as we fight to complete the acquisition. 
Now let's take a very quick look at the fourth quarter results for each of our business units. And I'm going to start with the North American Commercial. Their sales were flat year-over-year, excluding the negative impact of changes in FX rates. On a GAAP basis, sales in the U.S. dollars were down 1% to $2 billion versus last year. And contract sales were also flat on a local currency business -- basis. 
As I mentioned at the beginning of the call, we continued to drive good growth in categories beyond office supplies and contract during Q4. We achieved double-digit sales growth in breakroom supplies and promotional products. And sales were up in high single digits in facility supplies. This momentum was offset by modest sales decline in our contract print and technology business. We also felt a headwind in contract furniture where we're up against sales growth of more than 30% in Q4 last year. Contract sales in core office categories like ink and toner and paper were down in the low single digits, and sales of office supplies increased about 1% versus the prior year.  During the fourth quarter, North American Commercial operative margin rate increased 57 basis points to 7.6% and operating income grew $10 million. This improvement primarily reflects increased product margin rate and lower incentive compensation expense of versus Q4 of last year, and this was partially offset by investments in sales force to drive growth in categories beyond office supplies. 
Turning to North American Stores and Online. Sales declined approximately 4%, excluding the negative impact of changes in foreign exchange rates and store closures. On a GAAP basis, sales decline 9% to $2.4 billion versus Q4 of last year. During the fourth quarter, combined North American Stores and Online comparable sales declined by 4%. This reflects 1% local currency sales growth in Staples.com and a 5% decline in same-store sales. Same-store sales were negatively impacted by about 1% as a result of our decision to close our stores on Thanksgiving Day. Results in Canada were stronger than in the U.S. in both stores and online during the fourth quarter. 
From a category perspective. The 5% decline in same-store sales during Q4 was entirely driven by ongoing weakness in technology, computers, mobility, playing hardware and technology accessories all declined in the double digits. Given the margin characteristics of technology hardware, the impact on the bottom line was not as dramatic as the sales headwind from technology. 
Outside of technology, same-store sales were about flat during the fourth quarter. This was driven by growth in copy and print and mail and ship supplies and relatively flat sales in office supplies and furniture year-over-year.  
North American Stores & Online operating margin increased 14 basis points year-over-year to 5.1%. This primarily reflects improved product margin rates and lower incentive compensation expense versus Q4 of last year. And this was partially offset by increased delivery expense, increased marketing expenses as a percentage of sales, and the negative impact of lower sales on fixed cost -- fixed expenses. 
Turning to International operations. Sales decreased 1%, excluding the negative impact of changes in foreign exchange rates. On a GAAP basis, sales in U.S. dollar were down 12% year-over-year to $791 million versus Q4 of last year. 
In our contract business in Europe, local currency sales were down in the mid-single digits during the fourth quarter. In Europe retail, same-store sales declined 11% during the fourth quarter driven primarily by decrease in customer traffic versus Q4 of last year. That's largely due to our less promotional approach during the holiday season. And in our European online business, local currency sales were down in the low single digits. 
As I mentioned at the beginning of the call, we continue to make great progress driving year-over-year growth and improved profitability in Australia, New Zealand and China. These improvements once again helped to offset some of the pressures we've been experiencing in Europe. 
On the bottom line, International Operations was about breakeven for the fourth quarter. Operator margin rate decreased 212 basis points compared to Q4 of last year. This decrease primarily reflects lower product margin rate in Europe contract and a negative impact of lower sales on fixed expenses in Europe, partially offset by improved profitability in Australia and China and in South America. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Christine to review our financials.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Good morning, everyone. Total company sales for the fourth quarter were $5.3 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, total company sales declined 2% versus Q4 of last year. This excludes a 4% headwind from changes in foreign exchange rate and a 1% hea
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Good morning, everyone. Total company sales for the fourth quarter were $5.3 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, total company sales declined 2% versus Q4 of last year. This excludes a 4% headwind from changes in foreign exchange rate and a 1% headwind from a stores we closed in North America during the past year. On a GAAP basis, sales declined 7% versus Q4 of last year. During the fourth quarter, we achieved non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.26. This was at the lower end of our guidance, and it excludes pretax charges of $172 million primarily related to the restructuring and the acquisition of Office Depot as well as the impact of certain tax items. On a GAAP basis, we reported net earnings of $0.13 per share. Gross profit margin for the fourth quarter decreased 6 basis points to 26.2% versus Q4 of the last year. This primarily reflects product margin rate increases in  North American Stores & Online, partially offset by lower product margin rate in Europe as well as increased delivery costs in North American Stores and Online. During the fourth quarter, total company SG&A decreased $85 million year-over-year after, after excluding a $36 million charge in Q4 of this year primarily related to the acquisition of Office Depot and the previously announced data security incident as well as $5 million of accelerated depreciation during the fourth quarter last year. This reflects the favorable impact of the stronger U.S. dollar and aggressive cost management across the company. As a percentage of sales, SG&A, excluding charges, decreased 7 basis points to 20.9%. In Q4, we wrapped up our 2-year cost-reduction program. As Ron mentioned, we did respond to softer-than-expected sales and earnings during the fourth quarter by taking aggressive options in streamlining our organization. As a result, we eliminated more than 1,000 jobs across the company in Q4 bringing our 2-year annualized cost take-out to approximately $550 million. Over the past 2 years, we've had great success reducing product cost, eliminating expenses in our retail stores, driving efficiencies in the supply chain and streamlining our European operations. Most importantly, we have changed the way we work. The lessons we've learned set us extremely well to continue driving cost efficiencies across the organization in 2016 and beyond. Excluding the impact of charges, non-GAAP total company operating margin rate was flat year-over-year at 5.1%. 
Turning to our Q4 tax rate. Excluding the impact of charges and certain discrete items, our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 33.5% versus our non-GAAP effective tax rate of 28.6% in Q4 of 2014. During Q4 of last year, contract extended at certain provision in the U.S. tax code that allowed for federal wage tax credit and the deferral of the income in certain foreign earning. This drove the favorability in last year's fourth quarter effective tax rate and resulted in a $0.02 tailwind to Q4 2014 diluted earnings per share. During Q4 of 2015, Congress extended the same provision as last year, but the favorable impact was offset by the year-over-year change in our geographic mix of earnings. In 2016, we are planning for our effective tax rate to be approximately 35.5%. We expect a modest year-over-year increase to be primarily driven by changes in our geographic mix of earnings versus 2015. Year-to-date, capital expenditures came in at $381 million, an increase of $20 million versus the prior year. With operating cash flow of $978 million, we generated free cash flow of $597 million in 2015, which was in line with our expectations. Throughout 2015, we carefully managed working capital. And at the end of the year, our AP-to-inventory ratio improved 91% versus 87% at the end of 2014. We continue to focus on building cash ahead of the Office Depot acquisition, and as a result, we did not purchase any shares during 2015. At the end of 2015, Staples had approximately $1.9 billion in liquidity, including cash and cash equivalents of $825 million and available lines of credits of about $1.1 billion. During 2015, we returned $308 million or about half of our free cash flow to shareholders through our cash dividend. We remain committed to maintaining our current quarterly dividend. And earlier this week, we announced a Q1 2016 cash dividend of $0.12 per share. 
Now turning to our outlook. As Ron mentioned earlier, we do expect to get back to earnings growth in 2016. During the first quarter of 2016, we expect total company sales to decrease versus Q1 of last year. We expect to drive growth in categories beyond office supplies and in our delivery businesses in North America. We will be -- this will be offset by ongoing weaknesses in technology and our retail stores, moderating headwinds from our stronger U.S. dollar as well as store closures. On the bottom line, we expect first quarter non-GAAP diluted earnings per share from -- in the range of $0.16 to $0.18. Our earnings guidance excludes any potential cost related to the company's planned acquisition of Office Depot and the impact related to ongoing store closures. We expect to generate approximately $600 million of free cash flow in 2016, and our cash flow guidance excludes financing payments related to the acquisition of Office Depot. In 2016, we plan to close approximately 50 retail stores in North America. This will bring our total store closures to nearly 300 since the beginning of 2014. 
I'll now turn it back over to Joyce, our conference call moderator, for Q&A.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Michael Lasser with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Michael Lasser with UBS.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The ability to drive profitable growth, you outlined in some of your prepared remarks initiatives you're going to take this year, including hiring more workers in the contract business and more specialists. At the same time, you're expecting to drive some
componenttext: The ability to drive profitable growth, you outlined in some of your prepared remarks initiatives you're going to take this year, including hiring more workers in the contract business and more specialists. At the same time, you're expecting to drive some earnings growth this year. So how do we bridge that? How do you get from making these investments all the way to driving earnings growth in what seems like a continue to be very challenging environment in the office supply sector?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, you're right. It's a challenging environment out there. But I think what we'll see in 2016 is the result of a lot of the investments that we've made over the last 3 years. We have been working really hard for the last 3 years kind of investing in ma
componenttext: Sure, you're right. It's a challenging environment out there. But I think what we'll see in 2016 is the result of a lot of the investments that we've made over the last 3 years. We have been working really hard for the last 3 years kind of investing in many areas of the business to improve them and position them for profitable growth. As I mentioned, we really only have 3 objectives this year. We're going to grow the mid-market, our most profitable part of our contract business. We're going to growth BOS growth because that's where the growth is compared to historically the office supplies is not growing like BOS has been growing. And we're going to focus on traffic. And I think we'll see some improvement in both retail and online traffic as a result of that focus. Now your question's a good one. How do you pay for all this new stuff, adding sales people and you're adding contract specialists, et cetera. All I can tell you is that we're pretty good at reducing expenses. We know how to do that. We've also kind of streamlined the organization. We changed the way we're working across the organization. And I think in 2016, we expect to pursue additional opportunities to reduce our cost. We took out $200 million in 2013. We took out another $250 million in 2014. And the year we just announced, we took out $300 million. And I think we'll continue to take out cost to support the investments as well as provide the contact to profitable growth and earnings growth that we've just talked about this morning in 2016. So we'll manage that very carefully, but we do anticipate growing our earnings this year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up question is on the contract business. You talked about some of the math stacking table, but Office Depot did talk about seeing accelerated disruptions from the uncertainty of the acquisition. So do you think that some of the businesses is
componenttext: And my follow-up question is on the contract business. You talked about some of the math stacking table, but Office Depot did talk about seeing accelerated disruptions from the uncertainty of the acquisition. So do you think that some of the businesses is going to maybe independent players in the market perhaps as some of the better contract account reps get moved around the industry or is that not happening?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me ask Shira to comment on that. But I think we think that Q4 was a particularly slow macro environment for the contract segment. But maybe Shira?
componenttext: Let me ask Shira to comment on that. But I think we think that Q4 was a particularly slow macro environment for the contract segment. But maybe Shira?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me first comment on Q4, the GAAP and then the independent resellers. So Q4 was black growth and SA. It was largely due to comping kind of extraordinary growth in the prior Q4. And in fact, our 2-year sales growth was relatively constant. And so when w
componenttext: Let me first comment on Q4, the GAAP and then the independent resellers. So Q4 was black growth and SA. It was largely due to comping kind of extraordinary growth in the prior Q4. And in fact, our 2-year sales growth was relatively constant. And so when we broke that apart, it was primarily due to some very atypical number of BOS wins in the prior year as well as a little bit on macro trends, but primarily the atypical BOS wins. It was also worth noting that our gap versus Office Depot has really remained constant over time. And if anything, it's accelerating a tad. Regarding the independent fielders, we don't have a sense really that they're gaining share. One of our best indicators is looking at Essendant and SP Richards. And while I think the dealers are shifting between which wholesaler they use, and that's driving some different sales momentum across the 2 wholesalers, we're not seeing a lot of evidence of share gain amongst the independent dealers.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Dan Binder with Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Dan Binder with Jefferies.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Few questions. First, for the full year, what kind of top line growth do you need to get earnings growth? My second question was, with international struggling for as long as it has, why not just exit that business? And then thirdly, given your comments o
componenttext: Few questions. First, for the full year, what kind of top line growth do you need to get earnings growth? My second question was, with international struggling for as long as it has, why not just exit that business? And then thirdly, given your comments on the FTC, should we assume that there are no new remedies being proposed prior to the court case?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Start with Christine on the kind of the top line needed to have profitable earnings growth?
componenttext: Okay. Start with Christine on the kind of the top line needed to have profitable earnings growth?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we look all our projections for 2016, we expect the sales to go down as we mentioned primarily between the FX impact and store closures. I think as we think about the our trends, we are planning trends that don't dramatically go up or down. And in that
componenttext: As we look all our projections for 2016, we expect the sales to go down as we mentioned primarily between the FX impact and store closures. I think as we think about the our trends, we are planning trends that don't dramatically go up or down. And in that context, between our cost out momentum, as Ron mentioned earlier in the call, we have been able to take out cost that's sustainable. So given that and given kind of some of the upticks that we've seen, and particularly in the North American businesses, where margins have improved, we feel confident in our guidance and our ability to grow earnings over time.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016

componenttext: And the second question, we have John Wilson on the phone. I'm going to throw that one to John to talk about how his kind of International business.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, thanks, Ron and Dan. As I look at the 2015 results, particularly for Europe where we're the most challenged. I think of those as temporary setbacks. The 2 biggest events that impacted our earnings, about 70% of that was foreign exchange related. Tha
componenttext: Sure, thanks, Ron and Dan. As I look at the 2015 results, particularly for Europe where we're the most challenged. I think of those as temporary setbacks. The 2 biggest events that impacted our earnings, about 70% of that was foreign exchange related. That's really a timing issue that's transitional. And the other 30% was related to our execution on a major new ERP rollout. Again, that's stable now, and we've got that largely behind us. So I wouldn't necessarily think about changing our entire direction based on the 2015 results. We certainly have the foreign-exchange changes now flowing to our both our cost and we're renegotiating and breaking contracts were needed to recover those costs as quickly as we can. So I think we're on a good trajectory in 2016 to recover the FX impacts. And I also believe we've got our new ERP system stabilized, we're running consistently for the last month at 95% flow rates within 24 hours. So I think we had challenges in '16, and we made real progress. Some of the other markets, as Ron mentioned, are actually doing quite well. We've actually improved both sales and bottom line of Australia and in China. So while we would never say never, I think, at this point, we're still looking at International Operations as contributors to our growth in 2016. And we think we've got the biggest challenges behind us in Europe.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Dan, your third question. I think it's obvious that we're preparing for the upcoming trial with the Federal Trade Commission that begins March 21. But having said that, and we said do this all along, we remain open to settlement with the FTC, and
componenttext: And then Dan, your third question. I think it's obvious that we're preparing for the upcoming trial with the Federal Trade Commission that begins March 21. But having said that, and we said do this all along, we remain open to settlement with the FTC, and we prefer that greatly over the idea of litigation. But at this point, I'm not going to comment on any discussions that we may or may not be having with the FTC.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So my first question relates to comments you made on your European divestitures. Can you size the business that -- of European regulators ask you to divest? And how much incremental business by revenue you've chosen to divest? I guess that will be the siz
componenttext: So my first question relates to comments you made on your European divestitures. Can you size the business that -- of European regulators ask you to divest? And how much incremental business by revenue you've chosen to divest? I guess that will be the size of the off European operations that were not per the mandated regulatory remedy.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Christine?
componenttext: Christine?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The divestiture, the request was specifically around Europe Office Depot and certain specific countries as well as some of the specific kind of global accounts. Based on how all the back and forth discussions with them, it was determined the best way was
componenttext: The divestiture, the request was specifically around Europe Office Depot and certain specific countries as well as some of the specific kind of global accounts. Based on how all the back and forth discussions with them, it was determined the best way was to divest all of European business. You probably know better, and you can kind of get their specific numbers from them in terms of the size of the market. But you can imagine that the kind of overall portfolio is fairly consistent to ours. From a profit standpoint, I think Europe is very challenging. And from over overall perspective, it doesn't materially impact our kind of plans, our synergies or anything of that nature.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And frankly, Matt, when we integrate the 2 companies, I mean, it's all going to be about the speed. And when you think about not having to deal with the integration of Europe, that allows us to focus where we think we have the opportunity and that's in No
componenttext: And frankly, Matt, when we integrate the 2 companies, I mean, it's all going to be about the speed. And when you think about not having to deal with the integration of Europe, that allows us to focus where we think we have the opportunity and that's in North America. So it almost makes it a little easier for us.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Thank you for that. Second question. If you could comment on the impact of incentive compensation -- lower incentive compensation, on the fourth quarter expenses, was that just the lower accrual? Or were there any accruals from earlier in the year
componenttext: Got it. Thank you for that. Second question. If you could comment on the impact of incentive compensation -- lower incentive compensation, on the fourth quarter expenses, was that just the lower accrual? Or were there any accruals from earlier in the year that you chose to reverse during the quarter?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was actually, as you can imagine, we've got specific metrics attached to our incentive compensation, and we didn't meet all of those metrics. So it was somewhat of a true-up in Q4 based on where the final results landed. Not to get into specifics, bu
componenttext: That was actually, as you can imagine, we've got specific metrics attached to our incentive compensation, and we didn't meet all of those metrics. So it was somewhat of a true-up in Q4 based on where the final results landed. Not to get into specifics, but it wasn't an overall significant impact on things, but it was definitely a catch-up for the full year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then finally, Shira, to dig a little bit deeper into the contract numbers. I hear you on the 2-year trend, which was pretty good number on that basis. If you think about what your customers are speaking about an experiencing now, there's obvio
componenttext: Got it. And then finally, Shira, to dig a little bit deeper into the contract numbers. I hear you on the 2-year trend, which was pretty good number on that basis. If you think about what your customers are speaking about an experiencing now, there's obviously a little bit of macro chop in the U.S. If you were to think about 3 different factors: One being employment; the second being any structural pressures on the business, paper consumption, et cetera; and the third being sort of austerity, purchasing austerity on a per employee basis, how would you rank them or would you identify them as particularly on people's minds right now in the business, more so than in the past?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't heard a lot about employment, and you guys track employment statistics the same way we do. And [indiscernible] Change or not a little bit later today.
componenttext: We haven't heard a lot about employment, and you guys track employment statistics the same way we do. And [indiscernible] Change or not a little bit later today.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Numbers were fine. So.
componenttext: Numbers were fine. So.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Austerity. Competitors are always looking for -- not competitors. Customers are always looking for competitive pricing, that's a constant, and that's not going to change. I would say, probably the biggest [indiscernible] that is the secular decline and th
componenttext: Austerity. Competitors are always looking for -- not competitors. Customers are always looking for competitive pricing, that's a constant, and that's not going to change. I would say, probably the biggest [indiscernible] that is the secular decline and the headwind that, that gives us. In a nice way, SPR's supply business has really held up and a lot of that is because our customer acquisition has been strong throughout the year. So that has really held up. But overall, it is the pressure of secular decline, which is why our strategy to drive growth through the beyond office supplies categories is so critical and why we're investing in the same slide digital selling, et cetera, so that we have the expertise necessary to drive [indiscernible] areas.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Albert Mantle with Evercore.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Albert Mantle with Evercore.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a follow-up question on the commercial side. So you just mentioned some secular decline. Maybe if you can could quantify for us what you think the industry is declining at ? What kind of rate? And then just specifically to the commercial side, I wan
componenttext: I had a follow-up question on the commercial side. So you just mentioned some secular decline. Maybe if you can could quantify for us what you think the industry is declining at ? What kind of rate? And then just specifically to the commercial side, I want to dig into more behavior of the existing customer and see, how did the sales to existing customers increase or fall over the last few quarters? And was that driven more via ticket or more via transaction?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shira?
componenttext: Shira?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So as I've guesstimate at the overall market decline and here I'm talking around our legacy categories of supplies ink and papers, about a negative 1% to 2%. In terms of the behavior of our existing customers, it's relatively constant. As I said, ou
componenttext: Okay. So as I've guesstimate at the overall market decline and here I'm talking around our legacy categories of supplies ink and papers, about a negative 1% to 2%. In terms of the behavior of our existing customers, it's relatively constant. As I said, our goal, our strategy and what the team is really executing to is to compensate for that core decline with BOS growth, and those are categories, which by and large have some growth in them where we have very, very little market share and where we have shown an ability to gain share. And from a customer's perspective, the real value add there is the vendor consolidation and their ability to go to one website and get everything delivered in one order. So over time, that also does enable us to, by and large, maintain our average order size as we see customers add items from new categories to order.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks. And my second question would be regarding free cash flow. You guided to about flat free cash flow year-over-year, but you have guided to growing earnings growth. Maybe you could walk us [indiscernible] through working capital there what you
componenttext: Great, thanks. And my second question would be regarding free cash flow. You guided to about flat free cash flow year-over-year, but you have guided to growing earnings growth. Maybe you could walk us [indiscernible] through working capital there what you expect in 2016?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As we look at the projections, we don't give specific specifics around it, but we do expect to grow earnings. We've also got capital where we would think that, that will be fairly constant, and we got working capital, which will be fairly constant,
componenttext: Sure. As we look at the projections, we don't give specific specifics around it, but we do expect to grow earnings. We've also got capital where we would think that, that will be fairly constant, and we got working capital, which will be fairly constant, although a little bit of an increase given our sales increase, given our earnings increase. As we look at some of the other areas within the free cash flow pressures that we've got, we've got our restructuring, which will continue to be about $100 million of payout. So net-net, it's never precise number, but that's why we think it will be about consistent with this year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Mike Baker with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Mike Baker with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One, another follow-up on the contract business and then one on the FTC issue. So on the contract business, just to be clear, so a lot of the focus will be on the beyond office supply categories. But did I hear right that for this quarter,
componenttext: Two questions. One, another follow-up on the contract business and then one on the FTC issue. So on the contract business, just to be clear, so a lot of the focus will be on the beyond office supply categories. But did I hear right that for this quarter, with the fourth quarter, that business did slow because you weren't able to sign up as many new customers as you did last year. And if that's the case, what was behind that? And does that worry you about your ability to grow that category in the future?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I am not worried about our ability to grow the category in the future. The real issue was that last year in Q4, we had -- we always have a couple of large wins in our customers every single quarter and that often is project furniture wins or very big
componenttext: No, I am not worried about our ability to grow the category in the future. The real issue was that last year in Q4, we had -- we always have a couple of large wins in our customers every single quarter and that often is project furniture wins or very big facilities win, and it just so happened, as luck had it last year, we had an atypical number of them in Q4, which we were now anniversary-ing this year. So we do believe that there's a lot of runway with our beyond office supplies category. It's obviously for larger customers, but also increasingly for our mid-market customers, one of our biggest challenges and something that the team is really making incredible progress on is how do you sell what we call the BOS categories to mid-market customers with the economics of bringing in imports and exports does not work bringing that to a smaller office. And so they've really developed a model with the combination of digital selling aids as well as virtual specialist, we can bring the expertise necessary to sell these categories to really any sized company. And we think that is going to be a big driver of growth for us going forward as well.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, that makes sense, it's really just a tough comparison I guess. The question on the merger and the FTC. If you can answer this. If their preliminary injunction does go through, there's some speculation that in some ways, that's sort of a do o
componenttext: Okay, thanks, that makes sense, it's really just a tough comparison I guess. The question on the merger and the FTC. If you can answer this. If their preliminary injunction does go through, there's some speculation that in some ways, that's sort of a do or die situation. But if it does go through, what's your next move? Do you continue to pursue the acquisition?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're -- if on May 10, Judge Sullivan grants the preliminary junction from the FTC, I think the acquisition of Office Depot is over from our perspective. As you would guess, we've been working on Plan B for several months at this point. And
componenttext: Well, I think we're -- if on May 10, Judge Sullivan grants the preliminary junction from the FTC, I think the acquisition of Office Depot is over from our perspective. As you would guess, we've been working on Plan B for several months at this point. And I think despite the fact that we're focusing all our energies and efforts on getting this acquisition behind us, but in Plan B scenario, there's a lot of things that we're working on. I think the strategic priority is going forward would relate to some of the things we talked about this morning, driving growth in categories beyond office supplies, growing mid-market, improving traffic, reducing cost, closing underproductive stores. So there's a lot of other areas that we have talked about internally that we're not prepared to talk about today. So our effort is, "Let's get this deal done and let's be ready for trial on March 21."

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Kate McShane Reid with Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Kate McShane Reid with Citigroup.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question was just on price investment and promotions. I know in the past you've talked about the effort to continue to refine price and then there was the mention today that you may ever find your promotions during the holiday period. So you can
componenttext: My first question was just on price investment and promotions. I know in the past you've talked about the effort to continue to refine price and then there was the mention today that you may ever find your promotions during the holiday period. So you can you help reconcile and maybe update us where you are on your pricing initiatives and how you're thinking about promotions going forward?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, obviously, there are times of the year when you have to be very promotional to get the people into your stores or on your websites, and we'll continue to participate in that. I think when you look at the fourth quarter, we decided that Black
componenttext: Yes, I mean, obviously, there are times of the year when you have to be very promotional to get the people into your stores or on your websites, and we'll continue to participate in that. I think when you look at the fourth quarter, we decided that Black Friday was an area where we wanted to play, but we weren't going to open our stores on Thanksgiving Day. And we probably stepped back on a little of the holiday giving away technology that a lot of retailers do in the fourth quarter. So I think our marketing rate will continue to be kind of similar to year-over-year. And at the same time, as we attempt to become even more competitive with online competitors, we'll continue to lower prices and we've been doing that for the last few years, and we expect that continue. Shira, I don't know if you have anything you'd want to add to that?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that captures it all.
componenttext: I think that captures it all.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. And my second question was on the billion-dollar potential synergies that you highlighted again today. Just given the announcement of divestitures, why is the $1 billion still the right number to be thinking if the deal were to go through
componenttext: Okay, thank you. And my second question was on the billion-dollar potential synergies that you highlighted again today. Just given the announcement of divestitures, why is the $1 billion still the right number to be thinking if the deal were to go through?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Christine?
componenttext: Christine?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kate, it's a good question. I think as Ron mentioned, I'm not worried about the European loss of synergies. I think we'll be able to accelerate more in North America. And I think that we'll have opportunity to kind of really challenge ourselves to go furt
componenttext: Kate, it's a good question. I think as Ron mentioned, I'm not worried about the European loss of synergies. I think we'll be able to accelerate more in North America. And I think that we'll have opportunity to kind of really challenge ourselves to go further and faster in North America. With the Essendant divestiture, it's -- we'll have to go through the details. But we have enough kind of a fake cushion in the thinking around that, that we think will be fine to continue to focus on at least $1 billion, and no need to change it at this point.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first, a clarification on the cost structure. The cost that have been recently pulled out of the business, maybe at the end of last year, if the top line stays the same, is that enough for the EBIT margin of the business to stay steady? Or is it pred
componenttext: Just first, a clarification on the cost structure. The cost that have been recently pulled out of the business, maybe at the end of last year, if the top line stays the same, is that enough for the EBIT margin of the business to stay steady? Or is it predicated on additional cost being taken out throughout the year?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon, I'll take that one. As we look at the cost structure, we think that we should be able to maintain that guidance that we've got and we'll probably look at the leverage piece that will depend on sales. But I think as we are constantly challenging ou
componenttext: Simeon, I'll take that one. As we look at the cost structure, we think that we should be able to maintain that guidance that we've got and we'll probably look at the leverage piece that will depend on sales. But I think as we are constantly challenging ourselves on execution around cost and being able to flex our business model and sales decline up or down, we're confident in the ability to manage towards the bottom line.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And a separate question. I think it's something that Ron had mentioned in the prepared remarks. I think you said that the $500,000 enterprise spenders are about 1% of your sales. Can you share what the size of the overall market is of those customer
componenttext: Okay. And a separate question. I think it's something that Ron had mentioned in the prepared remarks. I think you said that the $500,000 enterprise spenders are about 1% of your sales. Can you share what the size of the overall market is of those customers?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I said that there were 1% of our customers. They would be a larger percentage of our sales, probably in the high single digit range of our sales volume. And the other question was how large is that group as a percentage of total market?
componenttext: No, I said that there were 1% of our customers. They would be a larger percentage of our sales, probably in the high single digit range of our sales volume. And the other question was how large is that group as a percentage of total market?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I know the answer to that.
componenttext: I'm not sure I know the answer to that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would imagine it's pretty small given our market share is -- to include everyone across all areas. It is very small.
componenttext: I would imagine it's pretty small given our market share is -- to include everyone across all areas. It is very small.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my final question. I was intrigued by the comments about the mid-market contract investments. It sounds like those will continue even if the merger doesn't go through. But you mentioned that there were some challenges in selling them certai
componenttext: Okay. And then my final question. I was intrigued by the comments about the mid-market contract investments. It sounds like those will continue even if the merger doesn't go through. But you mentioned that there were some challenges in selling them certain categories, I think Shira mentioned that. Can you just give us a little bit, a better sense who these mid-market, I guess, players are? How much of your business and contract do they represent today? And then who are they getting serviced by and whether it's different categories or just different players?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gladly, Simeon. So the mid-market is currently about let's say 20% of contract sales, and it's our most profitable segment. I don't want your takeaway to be that it's a challenge selling BOS. Actually our BOS mix there is good, but we think there's even b
componenttext: Gladly, Simeon. So the mid-market is currently about let's say 20% of contract sales, and it's our most profitable segment. I don't want your takeaway to be that it's a challenge selling BOS. Actually our BOS mix there is good, but we think there's even bigger opportunity by really working the economics in getting the specialists in there more. The other thing I would say about mid-market is that it is a huge company opportunity, and that's something that this new organizational structure really facilities. So we have tens of thousands of them who are current contract customers, but we have hundreds of thousands of companies of that size. And I'm talking about companies roughly 10 to 250 employees who shot Staples either through our stores and online. So they like Staples, they know Staples, they shop Staples, but often as a secondary or a tertiary supplier. And we think we can use our existing relationships with those customers, and they just don't even know that we have a business unit like contract that can better serve their needs, given them the customized pricing and the personalized experience, the product expertise that they really know. And I think in doing that, we will grab share from a lot of folks out there in the market, we'll grab it from the dealer community, we'll grab it from retailers for things like breakroom, they buy a lot from warehouse clubs. We'll grab it from share play online. So it's a big opportunity for us, and we're very excited about it and have some good momentum.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016

componenttext: At this time, there are no further questions in the queue. I would now like to turn the call over to Ron Sargent.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just -- let me just wrap up in closing, I want to thank our associates. They worked really hard and they're very committed, and we had a lot done in 2015. We worked really hard to transform the company, and we worked really hard to get us through t
componenttext: Let me just -- let me just wrap up in closing, I want to thank our associates. They worked really hard and they're very committed, and we had a lot done in 2015. We worked really hard to transform the company, and we worked really hard to get us through the regulatory review process to acquire Office Depot. And I think we've positioned Staples to succeed, whether that's as a standalone company or hopefully combined with Office Depot. So thanks for joining us on the call of this morning. We look forward to speaking with you all again very soon.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 04, 2016
