During Q1, North American Contract continue to lead the way here with growth in promotional products, facility supplies, breakroom supplies, technology and furniture. We also grew key categories beyond office supplies in  North American Stores & Online during Q1 with comparable sales growth in furniture, facility supplies, copy and print, mail and ship and breakroom supplies. Another priority is to grow our mid-market penetration in Contract. During Q1, we grew North American Contract sales by 2% in local currency. Our strongest momentum was in the mid-market where sales were up in the mid-single digits driven by sales beyond office supplies, which is up about 10% year-over-year. Improved customer acquisition and retention offset modestly lower sales to existing customers, and this was supported by additional mid-market sales reps that we hired during Q1 as well as continued strong performance in our mid-market membership program. We also narrowed the focus on our best growth opportunities in contract during the first quarter with the announcement of our intention to sell our contract print manufacturing and operations business to Taylor Corporation. We acquired the contract print business when we bought Corporate Express in 2008. As we increase our focus on growing our asset-light businesses and improving return on net assets, it made sense for us to part ways with contract print. At Staples, we lack the scale and manufacturing expertise that this business requires. The business is also very capital intensive, generates an operating margin below the house and generates return on net assets below our cost of capital. 
While business is not a great fit in the Staples portfolio, it's a perfect fit for Taylor. We expect the deal to close during the second quarter. We look forward to continuing to offer a wide assortment of print solutions to our contract customers through vendor partnerships and our own in-store print capability. 
We're also focused on improving traffic, both in-store and online. Results here have been mixed during the first quarter. In Canada, traffic in stores and online increased year-over-year, and we improved customer conversion. In the United States, we also improved customer conversion in stores and online, but this was not enough to offset lower customer traffic across both channels. We remain committed to improving customer traffic online and conversion in stores. A few weeks ago, we launched the new unbeatable prices for ink and toner. And while it's still early, I'm pleased to report that customer feedback has been very positive, and we see a nice improvement in online traffic in the U.S. during the first few weeks of Q2. We know this is the right decision to improve price perception while driving business customer acquisition and retention over the long term. 
Over the past few years, we've had success driving growth in categories beyond office supplies, growing our mid-market contract business and providing better value for our customers by investing lower prices. Our momentum continued during the first quarter. Our strategic plan is supported by our strongest competitive advantages and builds on these successes. We're confident that by narrowing our focus and more aggressively pursuing our best opportunities will speed up our transformation, while positioning Staples for sustainable long-term sales and earnings growth. 
Let's take a quick look at first quarter results from each of our business units. I'm going to start with North American commercial. Here, sales were up 1% year-over-year, excluding the negative impact of changes in foreign exchange rates. On a GAAP pieces, sales in U.S. dollar were flat versus Q1 of last year at $2.1 billion. In contract sales grew 2% local currency during the quarter. 
As I mentioned a few minutes ago, we continue to drive strong growth in categories beyond office supplies and contract during the first quarter. We achieved double-digit growth in promotional products and breakroom supplies, and sales were up in high single digits in facility supplies. Contract sales in core categories like ink and toner and paper were down in the low to mid-single-digits, and sales of office supplies were flat versus Q1 of 2015. 
During the first quarter, North American commercial operating margin increased 63 basis points to 7%, and operating income grew by approximately $14 million or about 10% year-over-year. This improvement primarily reflects lower labor cost and reduced marketing expense. 
We expect the divestiture of Staples Print Solutions to close over the coming weeks. And as a result of the sale, we're planning for about a 4% headwind to our reported North American commercial sales and about a 2% headwind to our reported total company sales over the next year. 
Turning to  North American Stores & Online. Sales declined approximately 2%, excluding the negative impact of changes in foreign exchange rates and store closures. On a GAAP basis, sales were down 5% to $2.2 billion versus Q1 of last year. During the first quarter, combined  North American Stores & Online comparable sales declined by 3%. This reflects a 1% local currency sales growth in Staples.com and a 4% decline in same-store sales. Results in Canada were stronger than the U.S. in both stores and online during the first quarter. 
From a category perspective, the 3% decline in comparable sales during Q1 was highly driven by ongoing weakness in technology as well as weakness in ink and toner. In technology, tablets and technology accessories were our weakest category with double-digit decline year-over-year. Ink and toner were down low single digits. Outside of technology and ink and toner, comparable sales in stores and online grew during the first quarter. This growth was driven by furniture, office supplies, facility supplies and copy and print.  
North American Stores & Online operating margin decreased 40 basis points year-over-year to 2.8%. This primarily reflect the negative impact of lower sales on fixed expenses as well as lower product margins at Staples.com versus Q1 of last year. This was partially offset by reduced marketing expense, improved retail product margin rate and savings related to reduction in headcount. 
We continue to rightsize our retail store network in North America. During the quarter, we closed 14 stores in the United States, ending Q1 with 1,288 stores in the United States and 305 stores in Canada. We've now closed 256 stores or about 14% of the North American chain since 2014. 
Finally, turning to international operations. Sales here decreased 3%, excluding the negative impact of changes in foreign exchange rates. On a GAAP basis, sales in U.S. dollars were down 6% year-over-year to $738 million versus Q1 of last year. In Europe retail, same-store sales declined 9% during the first quarter driven primarily by decrease in customer traffic versus Q1. In our contract business in Europe, local currency sales were down in the high single digit during the first quarter. In our European online business, local currency sales were down in the low single digits. Despite the weak sales trends in Europe during the first quarter, John Wilson and his team in Europe did a great job aggressively managing expenses and, in fact, drove improved profitability year-over-year. 
Outside of Europe, we continue to drive solid growth in China during Q1 with sales up in the strong double-digit range in local currency versus Q1 of last year. We also continued to make progress improving the bottom line in Australia and New Zealand as well as China. On the bottom line, international operating rate margin rate improved 13 basis points versus Q1 of last year to an operating loss of 2.4%, and this was driven by year-over-year improvement in Australia, China and in Europe. 
And with that, let me turn it over to Christine to review our financial results. Christine?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ron. Good morning, everyone. Total company sales for the first quarter were $5.1 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, total company sales declined 1% versus Q1 of last year. This excludes a 1% headwind from changes in foreign exchange rates and a 1% head
componenttext:
Thanks, Ron. Good morning, everyone. Total company sales for the first quarter were $5.1 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, total company sales declined 1% versus Q1 of last year. This excludes a 1% headwind from changes in foreign exchange rates and a 1% headwind from stores we closed in North America during the past year. On a GAAP basis, sales declined 3% versus Q1 of last year. During the first quarter, we achieved non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.17, which was unchanged versus Q1 of last year. Our Q1 2016 non-GAAP diluted earnings per share excludes pretax charges of $66 million primarily related to cost associated with the proposed acquisition of Office Depot and store closures. It also excludes a pretax charge of $32 million related to the pending sale of Staples Print Solutions. On a GAAP basis, we reported net earnings of $0.06 per share. Gross profit margin for the first quarter decreased 33 basis points to 25.3% versus Q1 of last year. This primarily reflects lower product margin rate in international operations, and it was partially offset by improved product margin in North American stores. 
During the first quarter, total company SG&A decreased $59 million year-over-year after, after excluding a $24 million charge in Q1 of this year primarily related to the proposed acquisition of Office Depot, $11 million of acquisition-related costs and $4 million of accelerated depreciation during Q1 of last year. This reflects lower labor cost due to headcount reductions and store closures, lower marketing expense and a favorable impact of a stronger U.S. dollar. As a percentage of sales, SG&A, excluding charges, decreased 44 basis points to 21.5%. 
Excluding the impact of charges, non-GAAP total company operating margin rate increased 14 basis points year-over-year to 3.4%. 
Turning to our Q1 tax rate, excluding the impact of charges, our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 35.5% versus our non-GAAP effective tax rate of 33.5% in Q1 of 2015. This modest year-over-year increase in our effective tax rate was primarily driven by changes in our geographic mix of earnings versus 2015. Q1 capital expenditures came in at $44 million, a decrease of $16 million versus the prior year. With operating cash flow of $276 million, we generated free cash flow of $232 million during the first quarter. During the first quarter, we did make cash payments of $69 million related to the Office Depot financing commitment fees earned by our lenders in 2015. If you exclude the negative impact of these payments, our first quarter free cash flow came in at $301 million. At the end of Q1, Staples had approximately $2 billion in liquidity, including cash and cash equivalents of $946 million and available lines of credits of about $1.1 billion. 
As Ron mentioned at the beginning of the call, one of our top priorities is to continue returning excess cash to shareholders. We returned more than $300 million to shareholders annually through cash dividends, and we remain committed to our dividend program. We also plan to resume share repurchases during Q2. Our current forecast is for about $100 million of share repurchases in 2016. As a result, we plan to return approximately $400 million to shareholders this year through dividends and repurchases. 
Now turning to our outlook. We remain on track to get back to earnings growth in 2016. During the second quarter, we expect total company sales to decrease versus Q2 of last year. We expect to drive growth in categories beyond office supplies and our contract businesses in North America. This will be offset by the headwind related to the sale of Staples Print Solutions as well as ongoing weaknesses in technology in our retail stores and store closures. 
On the bottom line, we expect second quarter non-GAAP diluted earnings per share in the range of $0.11 to $0.13. Our earnings guidance excludes remaining costs associated with the proposed acquisition of Office Depot and the impact of ongoing store closures as well as the negative impact of the Office Depot breakup fee. We expect to generate approximately $600 million of free cash flow in 2016. Our free cash flow guidance excludes the impact of cash payments related to acquisition financing as well as the impact of the breakup fee that we will pay Office Depot this week.  In 2016, we plan to close at least 50 retail stores in North America. 
Over time, our strategic plan will drive improvement in both the top line and the bottom line. We will experience sales pressures as we explore strategic alternatives in Europe and as we continue to close retail stores in North America. These headwinds will be offset by mid-market growth, fueled by the categories beyond office supplies. We expect to get back to sustainable earnings growth as we reshape Staples and resume our repurchase program. We also expect Staples free cash flow and a significant improvement in return on net asset as we increase our focus on asset-light businesses, and reduce our exposure for our weakest performing businesses. 
I'll now turn it back over to our conference call moderator for Q&A.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our question comes from the line of Michael Lasser of UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our question comes from the line of Michael Lasser of UBS.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it seems like in the wake of the OEP situation, the strategy is now just to return to what the areas of focus that were in place prior to the deal and chip away you had working on, whether it's cost, growing categories beyond office supplies. How do yo
componenttext: So it seems like in the wake of the OEP situation, the strategy is now just to return to what the areas of focus that were in place prior to the deal and chip away you had working on, whether it's cost, growing categories beyond office supplies. How do you know that, that's the right strategy? or at least you're pursuing that strategy at the right pace? Why not make more aggressive actions and steps be the right path to pursue?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just give a couple of -- the reason we're pursuing this is because we took a good hard look with a lot of inside and outside help of [indiscernible] involvement project in the last several months with some outside resources as well. And we lo
componenttext: Well, let me just give a couple of -- the reason we're pursuing this is because we took a good hard look with a lot of inside and outside help of [indiscernible] involvement project in the last several months with some outside resources as well. And we look at kind of where do we compete best, where are our strongest competitive advantages? We looked is not only today but also kind of down the road. And basically, it builds on some of the things that we've been very successful at over the last several years. And whether that's kind of the opportunity of mid-market customers where we think there's a great opportunity to one, get more of them as well as sell more to them. Whether that's getting focused as more of a delivery asset-light company versus an asset-heavy company, and we talked about what we're doing with retail stores, what we've done with retail stores. Whether that talked about making are really tough decision about looking at opportunities and options relating to our European business. And I think in our situation and in declining industry, cost out is something we have to continue, and we've been a pretty good job with that as well. So I think those are the elements of the strategy. I mean, I'm sure anybody can say you're being too aggressive or not aggressive enough about particular part of the strategy, but I think we also, in a competitive situation, we're also looking to see how our competitors respond going forward, and we'll adjust and act appropriately going forward.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up question is, I think, we can have an easier view on where we think ultimately your sales will level off judging by the performance of the various segments. What's harder for us to grasp is how significant are the pools of discretionary ex
componenttext: And my follow-up question is, I think, we can have an easier view on where we think ultimately your sales will level off judging by the performance of the various segments. What's harder for us to grasp is how significant are the pools of discretionary expenses that you're drawing -- that you could potentially reduce further from here, and how do you balance reducing expenses with the need for growth? You kind of -- a couple of years ago, you invested a lot and you slowed the investment to triangle us a return on investment. What's the strategy [indiscernible] how big is the bucket and where do you go from here?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, when you're over $20 billion of revenue, all the buckets are large. Obviously, product bucket is the biggest bucket of product cost. And we think on brand represents a real opportunity to take cost there. Look at our second biggest cost will probabl
componenttext: Well, when you're over $20 billion of revenue, all the buckets are large. Obviously, product bucket is the biggest bucket of product cost. And we think on brand represents a real opportunity to take cost there. Look at our second biggest cost will probably be in the whole supply chain area, and we're looking at a lot of different ways of approaching supply chain, and at some point, when I know more about that, I sure can respond to that. So yes, the buckets are large and is always a balancing act. I think we said 3 months ago that we expect to earnings growth this year after 3 or 4 or 5 years of reduced earnings year-over-year as we've invested in the business. And I think this year as the year we said we're going to grow the bottom line. Do we expect to start growing the top line again? I do thing that's true. But as Christine said, we don't expect to do that in this year. So yes, it's a balancing act, and the buckets of opportunity are large.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Interesting. You mentioned that the North American product margins were up year-over-year in the first quarter. Was that just due to the lower penetration of technology? Or on a like-for-like basis were much margins up?
componenttext: Interesting. You mentioned that the North American product margins were up year-over-year in the first quarter. Was that just due to the lower penetration of technology? Or on a like-for-like basis were much margins up?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was actually a couple of things. One is asset light partly mix, but it was also to the point of that we have done a lot of hard work in looking at our promotional strategy. So getting more targeted on the types of the promotions that we have out there
componenttext: It was actually a couple of things. One is asset light partly mix, but it was also to the point of that we have done a lot of hard work in looking at our promotional strategy. So getting more targeted on the types of the promotions that we have out there and being able to move more of those dollars to everyday low prices particularly online. So you've been able to -- we've been able to figure out how to really balance of that type of the marketing campaign. And I would say that the U.S. retail has done a lot to grow their services business over time as well. So I think it's all of those things coming together, and that's why to Ron's point on the large pool, there are a lot of large pools, and we do have a variety of ways that are starting to take hold that we'll be able to pursue even more aggressively.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Simeon Gutman. So my first question, it was mentioned you were turning back to earnings growth. Can we speak to it in terms of EBIT or EBITDA growth? Is that going to be positive eventually? And in that same regard, the $300 million of cost savings over t
componenttext: Simeon Gutman. So my first question, it was mentioned you were turning back to earnings growth. Can we speak to it in terms of EBIT or EBITDA growth? Is that going to be positive eventually? And in that same regard, the $300 million of cost savings over the next few years, is that to offset investment? Or is some of that going to flow to the EBIT or the bottom line?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take that question. The earnings growth will come -- we haven't kind of definitively defined that yet because we don't want to give forward-looking guidance. But we definitely think it will be towards on the bottom line. And I think the $300 million,
componenttext: I'll take that question. The earnings growth will come -- we haven't kind of definitively defined that yet because we don't want to give forward-looking guidance. But we definitely think it will be towards on the bottom line. And I think the $300 million, it's going to be a combination of things. Some of it will go to the shareholders on the bottom line. Some of it will be used to invest in the business. And we will be flexible and we do think earnings will grow just in normal course, particularly on some of the contract businesses that you saw this quarter. So we'll continue to drive the growth through the sales of those businesses as well as the manage the $300 million opportunity that we've got.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then from a demand side, some of the categories -- some of the categories you sell face secular pressure. Can you talk about how that curve looks today versus how it did a year ago? Is the curve steepening when you look at ink and toner and pape
componenttext: Okay. And then from a demand side, some of the categories -- some of the categories you sell face secular pressure. Can you talk about how that curve looks today versus how it did a year ago? Is the curve steepening when you look at ink and toner and paper demand? Or is the rate of decline, is that holding steady?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's relatively steady. When you look at office supplies were shrinking and now they're kind of flattish. So office supplies and sales are going a little better. When you look at the ink, toner and paper, I think they've been down kind of in the 3
componenttext: I think it's relatively steady. When you look at office supplies were shrinking and now they're kind of flattish. So office supplies and sales are going a little better. When you look at the ink, toner and paper, I think they've been down kind of in the 3% to 4% over the last few years and that's continuing on. And in terms of technology, the technology, particularly in retail, that rate of decline is slowing. We're still very negative, but not nearly as negative as it was a few years ago.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, my final question on the marketing expense. I think it's helped across the board, but in both of the 2 North American delivery and the stores. Is there -- first of all, how did it come down? What type of spend came down? And was there a residual hit
componenttext: Okay, my final question on the marketing expense. I think it's helped across the board, but in both of the 2 North American delivery and the stores. Is there -- first of all, how did it come down? What type of spend came down? And was there a residual hit from that? In other words, not only an impact that you could see in the near term from less marketing, but could there be some residual impact over the next couple of quarters from it?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we look at the marketing expenses, we've really been very scientific and use a lot more of the analytics capabilities that we've been able to build in-house. So in general, the merchant in the marketing people will always say you going to lose some sal
componenttext: As we look at the marketing expenses, we've really been very scientific and use a lot more of the analytics capabilities that we've been able to build in-house. So in general, the merchant in the marketing people will always say you going to lose some sales, and that's probably true. But we think that we have enough offsetting opportunity with investing back in price. On the online side of the house, for example, and investing in some of the sales force in the digital tools and the sales force team in the contract business. So we've been very thoughtful about how we manage through the usage of that spend and really driving sales activities as laser-focused way versus kind of a generic brand focused that we've had in the past.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Baker from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Baker from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a couple of questions about that middle market opportunity. So can you help us by sizing what percent of your commercial business now would you consider middle markets and any commentary on what you think your share might be there? And the
componenttext: I wanted to ask a couple of questions about that middle market opportunity. So can you help us by sizing what percent of your commercial business now would you consider middle markets and any commentary on what you think your share might be there? And then a sort of follow-up is how that -- this initiative we're talking about today will be different than in the past? I've been covering you for a long time, and this is the first time we've heard about a middle market initiative. I just want to flesh that out.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the status, it's about 20% of our contract sales, and I'll ask Shira Goodman who's been heavily involved in this.
componenttext: On the status, it's about 20% of our contract sales, and I'll ask Shira Goodman who's been heavily involved in this.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first of all, mid-market, while it is primarily to Staples Business Advantage, it actually spreads across the company, and we have mid-market customers who shop in-stores, through Staples.com, Quill and SBA. And actually, that's a lot of the opportunit
componenttext: So first of all, mid-market, while it is primarily to Staples Business Advantage, it actually spreads across the company, and we have mid-market customers who shop in-stores, through Staples.com, Quill and SBA. And actually, that's a lot of the opportunity, which is how do we bring the different channels together and really have a convergence of force to go much more after. So from a North America perspective, it is closer to 10% or 15% of the total North American business. And we're already, today, growing and gaining share in this market. And the key on it is that these companies are large enough that they have more sophisticated needs and marketing, facilities, et cetera, but they're strong enough that they don't actually have the sophistication or the scale to have those in-house. So we are seeing that the value proposition of broad assortment, competitive pricing, very reliable delivery, plus the expertise that we bring is really enabling us to gain share, both from the core, but especially in the beyond office supply category.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so any idea what that share is currently?
componenttext: And so any idea what that share is currently?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the share in just across-the-board, our mid-market share is lower than it is small businesses or larger businesses because we've invested more in those other ends of the spectrum. And the core share is still very solid, the BOSS share is 1% to 2%, it's
componenttext: So the share in just across-the-board, our mid-market share is lower than it is small businesses or larger businesses because we've invested more in those other ends of the spectrum. And the core share is still very solid, the BOSS share is 1% to 2%, it's barely de minimis, and it's a huge opportunity.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, interesting. The -- of all of question. Just on the Staples. Print business that you're divesting. So we said it will be a 4% hit. What will it due to the operating profit in the commercial business, and will that be accounted for as a discontinued
componenttext: Okay, interesting. The -- of all of question. Just on the Staples. Print business that you're divesting. So we said it will be a 4% hit. What will it due to the operating profit in the commercial business, and will that be accounted for as a discontinued operation?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It will be probably be negligible to the bottom line because it does have a lot of capital, a lot of intensity on the actual operations side of it. We dont expect a significant hit. And it will go into -- although we'll probably sell it pretty quickly,
componenttext: It will be probably be negligible to the bottom line because it does have a lot of capital, a lot of intensity on the actual operations side of it. We dont expect a significant hit. And it will go into -- although we'll probably sell it pretty quickly, so it will flow through discontinued unless it's just a complete sale in Q2.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Fassler from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Fassler from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, part of it was asked prior, but as you think about the decline both in marketing cost as a percent of sales and also lower labor expenses for North American delivery and the nice margin expansion that you saw there, without issuing guid
componenttext: My first question, part of it was asked prior, but as you think about the decline both in marketing cost as a percent of sales and also lower labor expenses for North American delivery and the nice margin expansion that you saw there, without issuing guidance, which I know you're reluctant to do, would you say that margin expansion is feasible there over the course of the year going forward with the kind of sales performance that you put up in Q1?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Christine. Actually, I think, as you know, we focus on dollar growth, so that's kind of our emphasis here. Having said that, we've had kind of nice steady return here and we expect that to continue throughout the year.
componenttext: It's Christine. Actually, I think, as you know, we focus on dollar growth, so that's kind of our emphasis here. Having said that, we've had kind of nice steady return here and we expect that to continue throughout the year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so in other words, the investment levels have gone in such that with the limited top line that you should be able to at least told on profitability in any day?
componenttext: Okay, so in other words, the investment levels have gone in such that with the limited top line that you should be able to at least told on profitability in any day?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's how we started to see it. And you see the returns coming through on some of these investments we've made.
componenttext: Yes, I think that's how we started to see it. And you see the returns coming through on some of these investments we've made.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Second question, kind of strategically, having just been very extended process and having gotten to know the competition, I guess, a bit better, maybe a bit differently. Now that you've emerged from this process, any new perspective you'll be will
componenttext: Got it. Second question, kind of strategically, having just been very extended process and having gotten to know the competition, I guess, a bit better, maybe a bit differently. Now that you've emerged from this process, any new perspective you'll be willing to offer about where you all think you have particular competitive strengths and areas where you feel compelled to improve the business relative to competition?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, yes, obviously, I do want to talk about Amazon Business specifically. But our views there haven't changed at all. We still think they're very strong competitor in retail and the Staples.com and in Contract. We believe that to be successful in
componenttext: Yes, I mean, yes, obviously, I do want to talk about Amazon Business specifically. But our views there haven't changed at all. We still think they're very strong competitor in retail and the Staples.com and in Contract. We believe that to be successful in this industry, we've got to be competitive on assortment. We've got to be competitive on prices and delivery capabilities. And I think our differentiation going forward, not only stem some business but anybody we're going to differentiate based on expertise that we can provide the mid-market as well as services that we can provide the mid-market. I think we got a lot of initiatives underway that 0 in on that mid-market segment. And at the same time, I can tell you, I think stores still provide a competitive advantage for us. People still want to shop on the store, online purchasing is still like, I think in this whole country, is about 20% of retail. So 80% is still going on in stores. There may be too many stores out there, and I would agree with that. And I think there will be fewer stores going forward. But I think stores represent a competitive advantage. I think our specialized focus on the office products and mid-market is going to be competitive advantage versus others. I think when you're buying as much products as we're buying, we should be able to buy very well in the industry. So there's a lot of competitive advantages, I believe we have not only against traditional office products suppliers, but also I think increasingly going forward against Amazon.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then finally, I think you walked through some of the residual cash cost associated with the merger. I know that your store closing program has cash cost associated with it. As we think about free cash flow and model it out for 2016, Christine, what's
componenttext: And then finally, I think you walked through some of the residual cash cost associated with the merger. I know that your store closing program has cash cost associated with it. As we think about free cash flow and model it out for 2016, Christine, what's the aggregate dollar amount above and beyond your GAAP earnings in some sort of traditional CapEx, et cetera, that we need to think about to get to a year end cash number?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've got about $100 million on average related to the restructuring and kind of the other cost that are unusual. We're not including the $250 million breakup fee. So we think that $600 [ph] million is probably the right number in the kind of ordinary
componenttext: So we've got about $100 million on average related to the restructuring and kind of the other cost that are unusual. We're not including the $250 million breakup fee. So we think that $600 [ph] million is probably the right number in the kind of ordinary course of business.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chris Horvers of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chris Horvers of JPMorgan.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to follow up on that question. So on the competitive advantage question. This past year, Depot has had a lot of challenges, signing up new contract customers. Can you talk about your ability to maintain that edge? Have you seen a lot of resumes fro
componenttext: Wanted to follow up on that question. So on the competitive advantage question. This past year, Depot has had a lot of challenges, signing up new contract customers. Can you talk about your ability to maintain that edge? Have you seen a lot of resumes from their sales force over the past year? Has that delayed OfficeMax supply chain integration benefit your business? How do you think you maintained this, I guess, competitive gap over the going forward?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shira?
componenttext: Shira?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've actually looked at that gap over -- on a couple of years, and it has been pretty steady that our contract or delivery business grow 600 to 800 basis points faster than Office Depot. So I don't think it's changing trend. When you look at what's dr
componenttext: So we've actually looked at that gap over -- on a couple of years, and it has been pretty steady that our contract or delivery business grow 600 to 800 basis points faster than Office Depot. So I don't think it's changing trend. When you look at what's driving that growth, we've been steady on customer acquisition, we've been steady on customer retention. And what's really driving that Staples Business Advantage growth is mid-market customers and categories beyond office supplies, and these are those, I think, are really core to Office Depot Contract business.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then so, okay, that's very helpful. And then, Ron, can you talk about what your vision or how you think about the number of stores, the right number of stores in North America or the United States for the office products industry? You've h
componenttext: Understood. And then so, okay, that's very helpful. And then, Ron, can you talk about what your vision or how you think about the number of stores, the right number of stores in North America or the United States for the office products industry? You've had some views in the past after going through this and seen how the business has transformed. How do you think about that going forward?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the customer is going to decide how many stores will be operating in the United States and who's going to be owning those stores. I think in the past, I quoted a number of something like 2,400 stores in the office products industry in the U.
componenttext: Well, I think the customer is going to decide how many stores will be operating in the United States and who's going to be owning those stores. I think in the past, I quoted a number of something like 2,400 stores in the office products industry in the U.S. I'm not sure that's a bad number at all, to tell you that the truth. When you look at today, I think Office Depot operates maybe 2,000 stores, maybe a little less. You look at Staples this morning, I think we said that we're in the 1,280, 1,300 range. So do I think there are too many stores that are to close together? I do. And I think our opportunity is going to be to focus on the delivery business and kind of rightsize our store network. But we won't be doing that alone. I think we'll also look at kind of competitive closings as well.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So is the strategy, you talked about, I think, 50 more store closures this year, so is the strategy twofold way for the leases to come up and at the same time, see how aggressive Depot becomes?
componenttext: So is the strategy, you talked about, I think, 50 more store closures this year, so is the strategy twofold way for the leases to come up and at the same time, see how aggressive Depot becomes?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the strategy is kind of optimize our retail network in conjunction with other people trying to optimize their retail network. I mean, you look at half of Office Depot stores within 5 miles of the Staples stores. You look at 70% to 80% of Office De
componenttext: I think the strategy is kind of optimize our retail network in conjunction with other people trying to optimize their retail network. I mean, you look at half of Office Depot stores within 5 miles of the Staples stores. You look at 70% to 80% of Office Depot stores that are within 10 miles of a Staples stores. So I think in terms of density, there's probably -- excluding the northeast, there's probably a density issue that probably has to be resolved as an industry, not just by us.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Makes sense. And then just follow up on the gross margin, I'm not sure if we covered this. The degradation year-over-year was actually more steep this quarter than in prior quarters, and it seems like it rolled over that last quarter. So what's driving th
componenttext: Makes sense. And then just follow up on the gross margin, I'm not sure if we covered this. The degradation year-over-year was actually more steep this quarter than in prior quarters, and it seems like it rolled over that last quarter. So what's driving that because it doesn't sound like the mix has really changed, tablets still being down a lot. Is that the piece of closures and the rent savings basically abating?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, it's pretty much in line with what we expected. We did have significant improvement last year. And this year, it's been a combination of the plan that we have within some areas to invest in some of our prices. It definitely deleverage the fixed ove
componenttext: Chris, it's pretty much in line with what we expected. We did have significant improvement last year. And this year, it's been a combination of the plan that we have within some areas to invest in some of our prices. It definitely deleverage the fixed overhead cost in our retail businesses in Europe and in the U.S. But it's also product margin rate improvement in the stores and in the European stores as well as we've been able to optimize some of those promotional offers that we've had. So it is in line with our expectation and our planning strategy across the different business units. So I think that's a little bit of what I would just to color around that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as we think about that going forward, do we annualize that or is the idea invest in price and drive sales and take out cost to keep EBIT margins flattish?
componenttext: So as we think about that going forward, do we annualize that or is the idea invest in price and drive sales and take out cost to keep EBIT margins flattish?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It will be by business unit. So we are definitely focused on managing, as I said, growing earnings, so you'll see it on the bottom line. And some business units, we will invest more in price. Our strategy on price is to be focused on the business unit whe
componenttext: It will be by business unit. So we are definitely focused on managing, as I said, growing earnings, so you'll see it on the bottom line. And some business units, we will invest more in price. Our strategy on price is to be focused on the business unit where the units and the velocity can grow the most. We're also very focused on the making sure that the other line item within that gross margin, including leveraging our supply chain, is still an opportunity for us.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kate McShane from Citi Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kate McShane from Citi Research.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had one question about Europe. I know during the merger process that I think you were looking for interested buyers in the Office Depot piece of the European business. I just wondered, in terms of interest, to the extent you can talk about it, what k
componenttext: Just had one question about Europe. I know during the merger process that I think you were looking for interested buyers in the Office Depot piece of the European business. I just wondered, in terms of interest, to the extent you can talk about it, what kind of interest that you could get, and how will the dynamics change now that it seems like both European businesses are probably up for sale?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Christine?
componenttext: Christine?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we were definitely working with the European Commission on the sale of the Office Depot business. And there was interest. So I think that the office supply business over there is very fragmented. It's very dispersed across all areas. So there was inter
componenttext: So we were definitely working with the European Commission on the sale of the Office Depot business. And there was interest. So I think that the office supply business over there is very fragmented. It's very dispersed across all areas. So there was interest, and I can't go into details around that at this point in time for our businesses and for their business, it's still too early. But I think that the key point is, it is a fragmented market over there. Our business is getting stronger and stronger with a leadership that is management of John and his team. So we'll see and keep you all updated as the process continues.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how long are you willing to give the process, again to the extent that they can discuss it, before maybe pursuing keeping Europe as part of the business and continuing to either restrategize or reformulate the business there?
componenttext: And how long are you willing to give the process, again to the extent that they can discuss it, before maybe pursuing keeping Europe as part of the business and continuing to either restrategize or reformulate the business there?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's still early in our thinking and there's definitely a variety of ways to manage the alternatives that we've got. So I think it's still too early to put this in a time line and specifics out there at this point.
componenttext: It's still early in our thinking and there's definitely a variety of ways to manage the alternatives that we've got. So I think it's still too early to put this in a time line and specifics out there at this point.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then if I can ask an unrelated question to those 2, and it's been talked about a little bit already, but with price investments. Can you tell us how you're thinking about how much further you have to go? How much more work there needs to
componenttext: Okay, great. And then if I can ask an unrelated question to those 2, and it's been talked about a little bit already, but with price investments. Can you tell us how you're thinking about how much further you have to go? How much more work there needs to be done? And ultimately, do you think you have to be the absolute lowest price in order to succeed and how you're balancing that?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it really relates to what segment of the business we're talking about. If you look at some of the largest companies in America, I mean, they're already buying very, very well. When you look at our online business, our retail business, I think
componenttext: Yes, I think it really relates to what segment of the business we're talking about. If you look at some of the largest companies in America, I mean, they're already buying very, very well. When you look at our online business, our retail business, I think there are some items that are -- we remain too high at. Online, a couple of weeks ago, we announced kind of very significant reductions in prices on ink and toner, which is the most sensitive item or one of the most price sensitive items for our customers. So I think our goal is to get close to anybody out there and the price-sensitive items. I'm not saying they have to be the absolute lowest, but I think you've got to be within shouting distance. And particularly, when you think about some of the other things that retail offers, there are some advantages of retail that maybe customers don't like expect you to be absolute lowest, but the other things that retail offers allows you to be a maybe slightly higher. So I think we look at pricing like everybody else does. We look at price sensitive items, we look at the elasticity of those, we look at the things that are kind of medium and, and we look at things that are not elastic at all. But I think, in general, over the last 3 years, part of the investment that we've made this result of the cost takeout has been to lower prices. And I think we still have a ways to go. And then finally, once you get into the contract area, you're negotiating prices item by item, in terms of off contract or on contract, and I'm not sure there's a lot more to be done there as we're pretty aggressively priced in the contracts side of our business already.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Greg Melich from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Greg Melich from Evercore ISI.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions. I'm really thinking about the longer-term plan of getting the 80% or [ph] 60% to the commercial side of business. The way you're planning to, Ron, was 2,400 stores for office product industry. What do you think is the reasona
componenttext: I have a couple of questions. I'm really thinking about the longer-term plan of getting the 80% or [ph] 60% to the commercial side of business. The way you're planning to, Ron, was 2,400 stores for office product industry. What do you think is the reasonable number for you as you look out now?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm not going to get into that. I'm not going to be sending out competitive messages about what we think our number is. I mean, we talked about closing 50 stores this year. I think we've talked a few years ago about closing 300, and I think with this
componenttext: Yes. I'm not going to get into that. I'm not going to be sending out competitive messages about what we think our number is. I mean, we talked about closing 50 stores this year. I think we've talked a few years ago about closing 300, and I think with this 50, we'd be about that 300. We don't have a lot of stores that lose a lot of money. We are trying to make sure that our lease obligations is getting as low as possible, so we do have flexibility going forward. But in terms of our number of stores, we're not getting there.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And, I guess, on the lease obligations, I think the rent expense now sits at around with $700 million. Could you let us know how much of that is in North America versus say, Europe, given that you're considering leaving their strategic options? And
componenttext: Okay. And, I guess, on the lease obligations, I think the rent expense now sits at around with $700 million. Could you let us know how much of that is in North America versus say, Europe, given that you're considering leaving their strategic options? And also my guess is the European lease terms are longer than North America, is that true for the average lease?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the average lease is a little longer. John?
componenttext: Yes, the average lease is a little longer. John?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just under 5 years in Europe right now is the average lease period. In the U.S, it's in the mid [ph] 3 years.
componenttext: Just under 5 years in Europe right now is the average lease period. In the U.S, it's in the mid [ph] 3 years.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And of the rent expenses, Europe higher on average?
componenttext: And of the rent expenses, Europe higher on average?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then last, on the other [ph] $300 million of cost reductions you guys have outlined. What cash cost would there be to executing on those?
componenttext: And then last, on the other [ph] $300 million of cost reductions you guys have outlined. What cash cost would there be to executing on those?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: What -- I'm sorry, what was the question again, Greg?
componenttext: What -- I'm sorry, what was the question again, Greg?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: What cash cost would there be, if any, to executing on the next $300 million cost-reduction plan that you announced?
componenttext: What cash cost would there be, if any, to executing on the next $300 million cost-reduction plan that you announced?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't gone to that level of detail, but I wouldn't expect it to be a significant change in that what was done.
componenttext: We haven't gone to that level of detail, but I wouldn't expect it to be a significant change in that what was done.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the ratio will be similar to what we saw in the first plan.
componenttext: So the ratio will be similar to what we saw in the first plan.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, maybe even probably a little bit less.
componenttext: Yes, maybe even probably a little bit less.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Dan Binder from Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Dan Binder from Jefferies.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back to the initiatives in terms of your mid-market. Obviously adding 1,000 new sales people and focus on that part of the market squarely focuses on the independent channel. And I was wondering if you could just give us sort of stated
componenttext: I just wanted to go back to the initiatives in terms of your mid-market. Obviously adding 1,000 new sales people and focus on that part of the market squarely focuses on the independent channel. And I was wondering if you could just give us sort of stated the industry update on the independent that you see it and whether you think it's going to require just your brute force in terms of putting sales people out there or incremental price investment versus how you price that segment today?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think it is both the offering to the customer and how we approach the customers. So it is expanding our products and services that we really cannot, for the very full range of what they want, continuing our competitive pricing, as Ron said, because w
componenttext: So I think it is both the offering to the customer and how we approach the customers. So it is expanding our products and services that we really cannot, for the very full range of what they want, continuing our competitive pricing, as Ron said, because we are competitive in this area and the delivery. And for mid-market actually, omni has some value. They like to pick it up in store at times, same-day shipping will be leveraging our retail network and slows things like printing, the same-day satisfaction it is valuable to them. And then the secret sauce is really the expertise that we bring to the mid-market customers. And that's where it's a combination of our sales force, and yes, we will be adding 1,000 sales people. But really combining them and empowering them with data and digital assets. And it's really in that mix that we think we can gain share very cost effectively and differentiate ourselves from the other competitors in the market.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That independence has largely been successful with -- I would probably describe it as an [indiscernible] customer service. And Staples being a big organization, has good customer service, but I suspect some of the mom-and-pop businesses out there have the
componenttext: That independence has largely been successful with -- I would probably describe it as an [indiscernible] customer service. And Staples being a big organization, has good customer service, but I suspect some of the mom-and-pop businesses out there have these long-term relationships with independence. So how do you overcome that? How do you really distinguish your service levers versus that mom-and-pop player?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we distinguish our service levels with our execution of it. Our supply chain is -- we'll be going strong. Their service levels and by adding the sales people that does enable more of the one-to-one personal touch that sometimes it does take to dif
componenttext: I think we distinguish our service levels with our execution of it. Our supply chain is -- we'll be going strong. Their service levels and by adding the sales people that does enable more of the one-to-one personal touch that sometimes it does take to differentiate from it. And the final piece that I would add to it is that increasingly, our customer base is changing as well. And they are becoming more digitally astute, they're used to buying online, and therefore, our digital capabilities, which far outpace the independent dealers, we see time and time again, is really being a lever to grow their share.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Great. If I can just follow up on other question -- well, 2 actually. One, could you just comment on the cadence for the quarter? I noticed some retailers out there that talked about slow down in April, some are attributing it to weather would not
componenttext: Got it. Great. If I can just follow up on other question -- well, 2 actually. One, could you just comment on the cadence for the quarter? I noticed some retailers out there that talked about slow down in April, some are attributing it to weather would not affect you, but some more macro-type commentary. So if you could comment on that. And then the last one was just regarding these BOSS categories because obviously outlined some that you're pursuing today. I'm just curious if there's any sort of new categories that you would be willing to share with us today that are coming up on your radar?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of the cadence of the quarter, I mean, we're one of those lucky retailers that are February, March, April quarter, so Easter is kind of typically always in our quarter. Sometimes it's late in the quarter, sometimes it's early in the quarter. So i
componenttext: In terms of the cadence of the quarter, I mean, we're one of those lucky retailers that are February, March, April quarter, so Easter is kind of typically always in our quarter. Sometimes it's late in the quarter, sometimes it's early in the quarter. So in terms of cadence, we were affected by the Easter shift, and it came back to us the following month. In terms of BOSS categories, Shira?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, we have a very broad offering today when you think about everything from facilities to prints, promo, tech, furniture, but 1 category that we're particularly exciting about and is leading that pack in growth rate is breakroom. And that is act
componenttext: I would say, we have a very broad offering today when you think about everything from facilities to prints, promo, tech, furniture, but 1 category that we're particularly exciting about and is leading that pack in growth rate is breakroom. And that is actually coffee is the core there, but in and everything that surrounds coffee, including food and snacks, et cetera, and that's a real growth area overall. I think as companies use breakroom as a way to attract talent and build culture, and it's a real opportunity for us that's paying off.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from the line of Anthony Chukumba from BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of Anthony Chukumba from BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my first question. Could you just give us a quick update in terms of sales transfer rate from strong closed stores?
componenttext: I guess my first question. Could you just give us a quick update in terms of sales transfer rate from strong closed stores?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, I think, just to give you big picture. When we closed a store, about 70% affect another store. And there's about 30% of the time where we don't have any store anywhere close. So there's no transfer there. When we look at the 70% where there
componenttext: Sure. I mean, I think, just to give you big picture. When we closed a store, about 70% affect another store. And there's about 30% of the time where we don't have any store anywhere close. So there's no transfer there. When we look at the 70% where there is a transfer, it's roughly 20%. And I understand that Office Depot is getting a little higher transfer rate, but my guess is the stores that they're closing will be OfficeMax, Office Depot stores that are closer together. So it runs around 20% for the stores where we do have competition. If you put those 30% in and we don't have any stores close by, we'll probably be in the 15% to 17%.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then my last question was related to, I guess this new Labor Department regulation where they're increasing the threshold of salary for, I guess, employees that are eligible for overtime. And I guess I'm just wondering, and may
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then my last question was related to, I guess this new Labor Department regulation where they're increasing the threshold of salary for, I guess, employees that are eligible for overtime. And I guess I'm just wondering, and maybe too early, but I mean, first off, do you see this having an impact at all in terms of your North American retail stores? And what steps can you take to sort of offset that?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, obviously it's very early days, so we haven't done any math. But I can tell you that we were kind of very early on this one because we operate a lot of stores in California. And several years ago, we reclassified some of those assistant manag
componenttext: Yes. I mean, obviously it's very early days, so we haven't done any math. But I can tell you that we were kind of very early on this one because we operate a lot of stores in California. And several years ago, we reclassified some of those assistant managers to hourly just because of this issue. So I think we're pretty far ahead on the issue. And most of our managers work -- our system managers are kind of working similar to kind of our store managers. We don't have a lot of 80-hour week manager types like you might have heard about in some of the press.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Ron Sargent for any closing remarks.
componenttext: Thank you. And I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Ron Sargent for any closing remarks.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just wrap up by saying thanks for joining us on the call this morning. We look forward to speaking to all of you again very soon.
componenttext: I'll just wrap up by saying thanks for joining us on the call this morning. We look forward to speaking to all of you again very soon.
