So it goes without saying that a lot has changed over the past 24 years as Staples has evolved from a retail company with a fledgling delivery business to a delivery company with a retail business. And yet, for all the change that I've been part of, the most important thing about our company has remained constant--our commitment to our business customers and to transforming to meet their changing needs. 
So June 15 was my first day on the job, and I dove right in. My top priority is to position our company for sustainable, long-term sales and earnings growth. And we're doing that via our Staples 2020 strategy.  This strategy includes a dramatic change in our mindset and our operating model. We're doubling down on Staples Business Advantage, our North American contract business, where we have solid momentum on both the top and bottom line as well as a best-in-class offering to build on. At the same time, we're focusing on maximizing profitability and reducing risk in our underperforming retail and European businesses. 
I'm confident that our future is bright, and the reason I'm so confident is because our strengths so far outnumber our challenges. We have what we need to win. 
Nearly 2 million customers visit our websites and our stores everyday. We have a world-class distribution network that provides next-day delivery to business customers of all sizes. Half of our sales now come from categories beyond office supplies, [ph] and we have expertise in these adjacent categories that allows us to expand our share of wallet with customers. 
Well over half of our sales are generated online through our private and public websites. We have leading e-commerce and digital capabilities. Our brand is widely known and well-respected. Our balance sheet is strong and we have ample liquidity to support our long-term growth priorities. And most importantly, we have an incredible team of engaged and committed associates. 
On May 11, we announced our Staples 2020 strategy, which builds on all the strengths which I just listed but also address our biggest challenges. We have 4 critical strategic priorities: First, we're focused on winning in the mid-market in North America. I've spent a lot of time on this business over the years, and I couldn't be more optimistic about this opportunity. Second, preserving profitability in our North American stores. Third, taking aggressive action to further reduce costs and drive efficiency across the organization. And fourth, narrowing our geographic focus to North America by exploring strategic alternatives for our European operations. 
Now since launching Staples 2020, I've made some changes to our leadership team and our organizational structure to get the right talent in the right seats on the box. Joe Doody, our Vice Chairman, has assumed leadership for North American operations. You all know Joe. He's an 18-year Staples veteran, and he has been the key architect for building and leading high-performing teams across our North American delivery businesses for the majority of his time with the company. In his new role, Joe will focus on executing our Staples 2020 strategy, delivering on our 2016 financial goals and driving synergies and teamwork across our North American operations leadership team. 
During Q2, we also took an important step forward by more closely aligning staples.com and Staples Business Advantage under Neil Ringel, our Executive Vice President of Staples Business Advantage. Neil has been with Staples for 21 years, and for the last 5 years, has been leading our $7 billion North American contract organization and driving consistent growth. He is one of our most dynamic and capable leaders, and I'm excited about his expanded role. Also this improved alignment between SBA and dot-com [ph] will allow us to better serve our mid-market customers regardless of their ordering platform. 
As I mentioned a couple of minutes ago, we're focused on preserving profitability in our North American retail stores. Steve Matyas has been appointed President of North American Retail. Steve has over 25 years of experience at Staples, primarily leading our Canadian retail and online businesses. In his new role, Steve will also lead our U.S. retail business. His track record of delivering strong returns is well known across Staples. 
Finally, as we shared during Q1, John Wilson has taken on the additional responsibilities of driving our transformation for all of Staples, and he has been a real partner to me in doing so. 
And as our strategy evolves, I will continue making the changes necessary to put us in the best possible position to win. To that end, during Q2, we also held a company-wide leadership meeting to align the organization and make sure that each and every one of our leaders understood our new strategy and what was their role in making it happen. We've been adopting a transformation mindset, and I've been challenging the management team to lead with focus and accountability, speed and teamwork, what I call FAST, [ph] and have been delighted by the response and already visible changes in behavior. 
Now let me give you more color around the progress we've made on each of our Staples 2020 strategic priorities during Q2. Let's start with our top growth priority, winning in the mid-market in North America. 
We have a differentiated approach to serving mid-market customers where technology and innovation are at the core of our offering. This approach combines the personal touch of our sales force with digital selling tools and robust data on customer behavior and preferences.  Just to be clear, we define the mid-market as business customers with 10 to 200 employees, and they are a sweet spot for us. These customers are often large enough that they have sophisticated needs, but too small to have the expertise or resources for all of their needs in-house. Historically, our key differentiators in the mid-market have been deep assortment, very competitive pricing and fast delivery. Today, these differentiators have become table stakes. [ph] To win, we need to do more.  So we are accelerating our mid-market growth by leveraging our expertise and evolving our approach to customer acquisition, and we made some nice progress here during Q2. Mid-market sales grew in the mid-single digits versus last year, and this was fueled by double-digit growth in categories beyond office supplies [ph] as well as strong customer acquisition. We've enhanced our digital marketing and sales support capabilities, and by doing so, we are shortening the customer acquisition process and can significantly reduce the cost of acquisition. We also plan to double our mid-market sales force over the next few years and year-to-date, have already added over 100 mid-market sales reps, bringing our total to about 1,300 of mid-market sales headcount. 
Now we're not only modifying how we acquire customers, but we're also enhancing what we offer them. A growing percentage of our mid-market customers are taking advantage of our membership programs. These programs provide customized discounts and differentiated levels of service. The results are very encouraging, and we're seeing increased spend and loyalty from tens of thousands of businesses who have signed up for our membership program so far. 
And additionally, we're planning to utilize M&A as a growth catalyst. We've restarted our process of pursuing acquisitions to accelerate our mid-market strategy, and we're actively managing a strong pipeline of opportunities. 
Moving on to North American stores. Here, our top priority is to preserve profitability. Let me take a minute to give you some color on how we're managing the retail business. 
While our stores provide business customers with a level of service and convenience that differentiates Staples from the competition, I do want to be clear that we're not positioning our retail business as a key driver of long-term sales and earnings growth. That said, our stores generate a significant amount of free cash flow, and this cash is critical as we invest to reposition Staples by accelerating growth in mid-market and categories beyond office supplies. [ph] 
This year, our stores in North America are on track to generate over $200 million of free cash flow, which we're taking aggressive actions to preserve despite weak traffic. Our team is driving increased customer conversion, growing our high-margin copy and print and text service set; [ph] evolving our promotional strategies; optimizing our marketing spend; focusing on reducing fixed costs, in line with sales decline; driving double-digit growth in key omni-channel capabilities like buy online and pickup in store; [ph] and we're achieving record level of customer service. 
But at the same time, we know we need to respond to changing customer behavior by continuing to reduce our retail footprint. Over the past 3 years, we've closed more than 300 stores in North America, and we're on track to close at least 50 stores this year. And over the next 3 years, an average of 225 store leases will expire per year in North America. This gives us tremendous flexibility to continue rightsizing our store network as appropriate without incurring significant cash costs. 
Our third strategic priority is cost reduction. As you know, over the past 3 years, we've eliminated $750 million of annualized pretax costs. And while we've made great progress taking out costs, I know we can continue to do things better, faster and cheaper. To that end, I've asked our teams to challenge the way we work and not be afraid to take on calculated risks to achieve our savings goals. We've initiated a new multiyear cost savings plan, which is expected to generate an additional $300 million of annualized pretax cost savings by 2018. 
I'm excited about this work. Our biggest opportunities are reducing product costs, increasing our mix of higher margin Staples brand products, driving productivity in our supply chain and evolving our promotional strategies. Many of these new savings initiatives are already underway, and we are on track to achieve approximately $70 million of annualized pretax cost savings during 2016. 
Finally, I'm pleased to report that we're progressing with our process to explore strategic alternatives for our European operation. John Wilson and his team have done a good job restructuring and streamlining Europe over the past few years, and this has positioned us very well.  We've seen a strong level of interest. And during Q2, our European management team met with a number of prospective buyers. We're currently working through due diligence, and we'll provide further details as the process continues. 
So to sum up, at Staples, we're in the early innings of a dynamic and pronounced strategic repositioning. We're moving from a product focus to a customer focus. We're moving from a retail culture to a delivery culture. We're evolving from a high-low pricing strategy to more everyday value. We're transitioning from a products company to a products and services company. We're utilizing M&A as a catalyst to augment our capabilities and drive growth, and we're narrowing our geographic footprint as we move from a broad international reach to a more pronounced focus on North America.  
And over the coming years, as we execute 2020, we will dramatically change the profile of our company. More than 95% of our sales will come from North America. More than 80% of our sales will be delivered, and more than 60% of our sales will come from categories beyond office supplies. [ph] 
So with that context, now let's take a quick look at Q2 results for each of our business units. Let's start with North America Commercial. Sales were up 1% year-over-year, excluding the negative impact of foreign exchange rates and the sale of Staples Print Solutions business. On a GAAP basis, sales in U.S. dollars were flat versus last year at $2 billion.  In Staples Business Advantage, our North American contract business, Q2 sales grew 3% in local currency after excluding the headwind from the Staples Print Solutions sale. We continued to drive strong growth in categories beyond office supplies. [ph] Sales were up in the double digits in facility supplies, promotional products and breakroom supplies. We also drove mid-single-digit sales growth in technology. 
Staples Business Advantage sales in core categories like ink and toner were down in the mid-single digits, and sales of paper and office supplies declined in the low single digits. 
During Q2, North American Commercial operating income rate increased 40 basis points to 7.1%, and operating income grew by $8 million or about 6% compared to last year. This improvement primarily reflects lower labor costs, partially offset by lower product margin rates. We also closed on the sale of our noncore Staples Print Solutions in early January. And just as a reminder, we're planning for about a 4% headwind to our reported North American Commercial sales and about a 2% headwind to our reported total company sales until we anniversary this sale during Q2 of next year. 
Turning to North America Stores and Online. Sales declined approximately 4%, excluding the negative impact of foreign exchange rates and store closures. On a GAAP basis, sales declined 6% to $2 billion. During Q2, combined North American Stores and Online comparable sales declined by 4%. This reflects 1% local currency sales growth in Staples.com and a 5% decline in same-store sales, primarily driven by a decline in customer traffic. 
Results in Canada were stronger than the U.S. in both stores and online. 
From a category perspective, the 4% decline in comparable sales during Q2 was almost entirely driven by ongoing weakness in tech categories like business machines and tech accessories, as well as ink and toner. These were all down in the mid to high single digits. For the rest of our categories, comparable sales in stores and online were down in the low single digit. 
North American Stores and Online operating income decreased 73 basis points to 0.6%. This reflects the negative impact of lower sales on fixed expenses in our stores, partially offset by improved profitability in Staples.com. 
We continued to rightsize our retail store network in North America, closing 19 stores in the U.S. during the first half of 2016. And I must note that the all-important back-to-school season is upon us with
[Audio Gap]
or pick them up in store. We're also providing customers with the peace of mind that they're getting great value through our LESS List pricing and 110% lowest price guarantee. 
Finally, turning to International Operations. Sales decreased 4%, excluding the negative impact of changes in foreign exchange rates. 
On a GAAP basis, sales in U.S. dollars were down 7% year-over-year to $721 million versus last year. In Europe, sales remained soft and were down in the low double digits in local currency. Outside of Europe, our strongest results were in China, where sales were up in the strong double digits year-over-year. 
On the bottom line, operating income rate for International Operations increased 91 basis points to an operating loss of 1.9%. The team in Europe once again did a nice job managing expenses and drove the majority of our reduced International losses year-over-year. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Christine to review our Q2 financial results and outlook in more detail.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Shira, and let me start off by providing a little bit more detail on our Q2 results. Total company sales for the second quarter were $4.8 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, total company sales declined less than 2% versus Q2 of last year. This excludes
componenttext:
Thanks, Shira, and let me start off by providing a little bit more detail on our Q2 results. Total company sales for the second quarter were $4.8 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, total company sales declined less than 2% versus Q2 of last year. This excludes a 1% headwind from changes in foreign exchange rates and a 1% headwind from the combination of store closures in North America and the sale of our Staples Print Solutions business during the second quarter. On a GAAP basis, sales declined 4% versus Q2 of last year. 
During the second quarter, we achieved non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.12, which was steady versus Q2 of last year. Our Q2 2016 non-GAAP diluted earnings per share excludes pretax charges of $986 million, primarily related to the impairment of goodwill and other assets and costs associated with the termination of the Office Depot merger. 
On a GAAP basis, we reported net loss of $1.18 per share. During Q2, gross profit dollars decreased $67 million versus Q2 of last year, excluding a $4 million charge in Q2 of this year related to our decision to exit certain lines of business in our U.S. retail stores in connection with our strategic priority to preserve profitability. 
Non-GAAP gross profit rate for the second quarter decreased 43 basis points year-over-year to 25.2%. This primarily reflects lower product margin rate in North America Commercial and International Operations as well as the negative impact of lower sales on fixed expenses like rent and occupancy in our retail stores. 
On a GAAP basis, gross profit rate decreased 52 basis points to 25.1% versus Q2 of last year. 
Turning to selling, general and administrative expenses. During Q2, total company SG&A decreased $67 million year-over-year after excluding $24 million of charges in Q2 of this year, primarily related to litigation as well as $10 million of charges, primarily related to the proposed acquisition of Office Depot during Q2 of last year. Non-GAAP SG&A rate declined 53 basis points year-over-year to 22.2%. This reflects lower labor costs due to headcount reduction and store closures and lower marketing expense. 
On a GAAP basis, SG&A rate decreased 25 basis points to 22.7% versus Q2 of last year. Excluding the impacts of charges, non-GAAP total company operating margin rate increased 14 basis points year-over-year to 2.7%. 
Now turning to our Q2 tax rate. Excluding the impact of charges, our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 35.5% versus our non-GAAP effective tax rate of 33.5% in Q2 of 2015. This year-over-year increase in our effective tax rate was primarily driven by changes in our geographic mix of earnings versus 2015. 
Turning to cash flow. Year-to-date capital expenditures came in at $102 million, a decrease of $36 million versus the prior year. With operating cash outflow of $11 million, our year-to-date free cash flow was an outflow of $113 million as of the end of the second quarter. Keep in mind that the breakup fee we paid to Office Depot as a result of the termination of the merger agreement was a $250 million operating cash outflow during the second quarter. We also made cash payments of about $90 million related to the Office Depot acquisition financing, which resulted in cash operating outflow during the first half of the year. These payments are tax deductible, and we do expect to realize the majority of the associated tax benefits in 2016. 
At the end of Q2, Staples had approximately $1.7 billion in liquidity, including cash and cash equivalents of $775 million and available lines of credit of about $889 million. We remain committed to returning excess cash to shareholders. We currently returned more than $300 million to shareholders annually for our cash dividend, and we are also balancing cash deployment through our share repurchases with our strong pipeline of M&A opportunities. 
When we announced our first quarter results, we were planning for share repurchases of approximately $100 million in 2016. But given the strength and the attractiveness of our tuck-in M&A opportunities, we chose to forgo purchasing shares during the second quarter and preserve our dry powder. 
Turning to our outlook. We remain on track to get back to earnings growth in 2016. During the third quarter of 2016, we expect total company sales to decline versus Q3 of last year. We expect to drive growth in categories beyond office supply and in our contract businesses in North America. This will be offset by headwinds related to the sale of the Staples Print Solutions business as well as ongoing weakness in Europe, continued technology headwinds in our retail stores and store closures. 
On the bottom line, we expect third quarter fully diluted non-GAAP earnings per share in the range of $0.32 to $0.35. Our earnings guidance excludes potential charges related to the company's strategic plans, including restructuring and related initiatives as well as the ongoing of strategic alternatives for the company's European operations. 
We remain on track to generate approximately $600 million of free cash flow in 2016. Our free cash flow guidance excludes the after-tax impact to operating cash flow of approximately $340 million of charges associated with financing for the proposed acquisition of Office Depot and costs associated with the termination of the Office Depot merger agreement. 
As Shira mentioned at the beginning of the call, we are positioning the company for sustainable, long-term sales and earnings growth as we execute our 2020 strategy. 
I'll now turn it back over to our conference call moderator, Kevin, for Q&A.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Greg Melich with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Greg Melich with Evercore ISI.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'd love to think back a little bit over the last year, especially given what your former merger partner was saying about how they had lost some business yet if we look at your own commercial sales, they've also slowed. So I'm just trying to put
componenttext: I guess, I'd love to think back a little bit over the last year, especially given what your former merger partner was saying about how they had lost some business yet if we look at your own commercial sales, they've also slowed. So I'm just trying to put those 2 things together. Is it just the market is slower? And then the second question I had a follow-up on the retail side.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Greg. In fact, our Staples business, the advantage contract business has had steady to accelerating growth, and we do look at the gap between ourselves and Office Depot and for probably 8 quarters now, it's been consistently in the 600 to 800 basis
componenttext: Okay, Greg. In fact, our Staples business, the advantage contract business has had steady to accelerating growth, and we do look at the gap between ourselves and Office Depot and for probably 8 quarters now, it's been consistently in the 600 to 800 basis points. And this last quarter, it widened closer to 1,000 basis points. So we feel really good about our growth in Staples Business Advantage. It's driven by beyond office supply sales as well as customer acquisition. And just one  kind of fun factoid in this season of the Olympics, one of our beyond office supply categories was promotional products, and there's about 20 million pieces of T-shirts, water bottles, et cetera, currently at the Olympics that was produced and provided by Staples promotional products. So things like that are really driving growth from that side of the house.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I misspoke. What I meant to say was not just the contract side, where you have but on the retail side, where your comp is down say, 4 or 5, and I think theirs was, I can't remember exactly, it was down 1. That success translate over into the reta
componenttext: I guess, I misspoke. What I meant to say was not just the contract side, where you have but on the retail side, where your comp is down say, 4 or 5, and I think theirs was, I can't remember exactly, it was down 1. That success translate over into the retail side.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So I think there's just 2 things happening there. One is Office Depot has gotten a lot more benefit from their store closures. They've done more in the past year. And because they were closing competitor stores, they were much more approximate and
componenttext: Right. So I think there's just 2 things happening there. One is Office Depot has gotten a lot more benefit from their store closures. They've done more in the past year. And because they were closing competitor stores, they were much more approximate and therefore, a higher transfer rate versus we were closing all of our own stores. So that accounts for about half of the gap, and I would say regarding the rest, well our 2-year stack comp actually improved from Q1 to Q2. So from a minus 9 to minus 8. I think we at Staples all feel that we can, and we'll do better on retails. We have many initiatives underway. The team is already doing well with conversion and market basket and customer satisfaction, but we believe that there's -- that we can do even better. And as I mentioned in my script, Steve Matyas is now leading that organization and is taking a fresh look at it as well as transferring a lot of our learnings from Canada.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, and then the second follow-up was on the profitability of the retail business. I guess it follows on that. The margin down to 0.6%. Was it gross margin? Was it SG&A? Was there anything in particular there to highlight on categories that may have b
componenttext: Got it, and then the second follow-up was on the profitability of the retail business. I guess it follows on that. The margin down to 0.6%. Was it gross margin? Was it SG&A? Was there anything in particular there to highlight on categories that may have been driving that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll ask Christine to take that.
componenttext: I'll ask Christine to take that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Basically on the profitability side, the biggest driver was sales causing deleverage on some of the fixed costs during the quarter. As you know, this is a small quarter for us until we kick off into back-to-school season. So I think primarily gross margin
componenttext: Basically on the profitability side, the biggest driver was sales causing deleverage on some of the fixed costs during the quarter. As you know, this is a small quarter for us until we kick off into back-to-school season. So I think primarily gross margin pressure from sales decline. The rest of the P&L in terms of managing expenses, the team's done a great job leveraging things like the labor line and marketing expense where we need to.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Binder with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Binder with Jefferies.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a few questions for you. First on consolidation in the industry. You've seen a lot of dealers either going away or being acquired. I realize that they may be smaller in size and perhaps not normally worth the time. But since some of your competitors
componenttext: I had a few questions for you. First on consolidation in the industry. You've seen a lot of dealers either going away or being acquired. I realize that they may be smaller in size and perhaps not normally worth the time. But since some of your competitors are actually buying them, is this something that you would revisit as you talk about M&A?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do believe that as an opportunity for us. We call those tuck-ins. We actually have a history of doing them, and they're very accretive. We get a lot of immediate synergies, and the integration is fairly straightforward as well. So when we talk abo
componenttext: Yes, we do believe that as an opportunity for us. We call those tuck-ins. We actually have a history of doing them, and they're very accretive. We get a lot of immediate synergies, and the integration is fairly straightforward as well. So when we talk about our strong pipeline of M&A, a good part of it is in the dealer community.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: My second question was around the membership program that you spoke about in the contract space. I was wondering if you could just elaborate a little bit on that a bit and give us some color around how much -- how many sales dollars are in those programs
componenttext: My second question was around the membership program that you spoke about in the contract space. I was wondering if you could just elaborate a little bit on that a bit and give us some color around how much -- how many sales dollars are in those programs today, how fast they're growing, what the key attraction is.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll ask Joe to answer that.
componenttext: I'll ask Joe to answer that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dan. I won't give you all the information you're probably looking for but give you some idea here. It's great program that we've used primarily in the acquisition area of our mid-market customers. It gives customers one, the incentive to have larger
componenttext: Sure, Dan. I won't give you all the information you're probably looking for but give you some idea here. It's great program that we've used primarily in the acquisition area of our mid-market customers. It gives customers one, the incentive to have larger order sizes. It also gives them various discounts on key product areas, specifically price, ink and toner. It's a program that has shown early on its strength in terms of both retention and penetration within those mid-market customers. So we are very happy with the program and continuing to expand it not only for new customer acquisition but also with existing customers.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And my last question was regarding Europe. Your comments today, Shira, sound perhaps maybe a greater level of commitment in shedding these assets. I suspect you may be getting a little bit further along in that process, but my question really is ar
componenttext: Great. And my last question was regarding Europe. Your comments today, Shira, sound perhaps maybe a greater level of commitment in shedding these assets. I suspect you may be getting a little bit further along in that process, but my question really is around the ability to separate that business from a systems perspective, if you can give us a little color on the complexity of that. I think you were putting some new systems in there recently, and then when you think this might get done. Is it something that you can do with in the next quarter, by the end of the year, next year?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll ask Christine just to talk a little bit about the process, and John will talk a little bit about the ability to separate systems, et cetera.
componenttext: So I'll ask Christine just to talk a little bit about the process, and John will talk a little bit about the ability to separate systems, et cetera.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we are working through the process in Europe specifically right now. As Shira outlined, we're talking to different buyers. Management's been and local management's been involved in the process, and all is going well. You know how these things go.
componenttext: Sure. So we are working through the process in Europe specifically right now. As Shira outlined, we're talking to different buyers. Management's been and local management's been involved in the process, and all is going well. You know how these things go. You can never precisely determine time lines and kind of what the end results going to be, but we're working with our teams and working with different buyers, and we feel good about the process and the underlying people that we are speaking to. In terms of the systems, I will let John handle it. But from a corporate standpoint, most of the systems, as you know, Europe is -- from a U.S. perspective versus Europe, it's fairly independent. So there's always some overlap on the systems. But, for the most part, these local teams have very different systems than the North America team and therefore, kind of -- you never take systems lightly, but it's not a big overhang for us.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just as Christine said, the amount of overlap in our systems is actually fairly modest compared to many other organizations. Probably the most integrated system we have is our online system, and there, we're looking at a transfer service agreement th
componenttext: Yes, just as Christine said, the amount of overlap in our systems is actually fairly modest compared to many other organizations. Probably the most integrated system we have is our online system, and there, we're looking at a transfer service agreement that will allow us to replicate that system and move the source code over. That's probably the only significant system. The others are fairly straightforward, and we would not anticipate any significant issues of separating the 2 entities.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shira, my first question. You mentioned the need or the attempt to strike the right balance of investments in retail to preserve the cash flow. I guess, looking back over the last several years, is there anything that could have been done different, the p
componenttext: Shira, my first question. You mentioned the need or the attempt to strike the right balance of investments in retail to preserve the cash flow. I guess, looking back over the last several years, is there anything that could have been done different, the pace of store closings? Curious if you have a different view on the ultimate number of stores. Does it make sense to put, I guess, money capital or expense back into them to help, I guess, to slow down the rate of that decline?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think what we've done to date has been a good balance. As we've shared, we don't have a lot of stores that lose money, and most -- and those that we have had historically, we have closed to date. So what is left in our portfolio is stores that are pr
componenttext: So I think what we've done to date has been a good balance. As we've shared, we don't have a lot of stores that lose money, and most -- and those that we have had historically, we have closed to date. So what is left in our portfolio is stores that are primarily cash flow positive. So it is a very careful balance of it. Having said that, with leases coming up over the coming 3 years and close to 750 leases over the next 3 years, that does give us a degree of flexibility to really assess our store network and to what extent do we continue to focus and invest in it and to what extent do we even put more focus on our Delivery business.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I noticed computers were mentioned. I forget if it was in the press release or the call, but is that due to something internal or external? Is it just comparisons are easy, and there's some modest growth in the category?
componenttext: And I noticed computers were mentioned. I forget if it was in the press release or the call, but is that due to something internal or external? Is it just comparisons are easy, and there's some modest growth in the category?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what I mentioned, Simeon, was tech and actually most of the downdraft in tech in this quarter was more business machines and tech accessories. Computers actually were a drag on us last year, and the team has done a really nice job of that this year. Th
componenttext: So what I mentioned, Simeon, was tech and actually most of the downdraft in tech in this quarter was more business machines and tech accessories. Computers actually were a drag on us last year, and the team has done a really nice job of that this year. They have changed the assortment to make it more micro business focused. They've worked on the inventory levels, and perhaps best of all, our store team has improved the market basket associated with computers by about 20% year-over-year. So the team has done a nice job of stemming that issue.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my last question on contract in North American Commercial. Are you starting to get a sense, even anecdotally, that you're bumping against newer players? I mean, Amazon included in bidding with business contracts?
componenttext: And then my last question on contract in North American Commercial. Are you starting to get a sense, even anecdotally, that you're bumping against newer players? I mean, Amazon included in bidding with business contracts?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So despite what the FTC is saying, North American Commercial has always been a very competitive market for us, and I would say the competitive intensity is pretty constant. Yes, we are seeing some Amazon out there, but a lot of the competition still is th
componenttext: So despite what the FTC is saying, North American Commercial has always been a very competitive market for us, and I would say the competitive intensity is pretty constant. Yes, we are seeing some Amazon out there, but a lot of the competition still is the local dealers, and we do have very significant, I think, competitive advantages over them.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question focuses on retail specifically on pricing. As we've taken kind of a fresh look at pricing from time to time, it seems like there's still a pretty big gulf and a lot of higher velocity items between yourselves and your channel and some of the l
componenttext: My question focuses on retail specifically on pricing. As we've taken kind of a fresh look at pricing from time to time, it seems like there's still a pretty big gulf and a lot of higher velocity items between yourselves and your channel and some of the lower-priced out there, particularly online. And as I look at your comps, are you where you want to be? Are you willing to invest in price at retail just to stop the share bleed? Or do you feel like you'd rather have the gross margin structure that you have and manage down the sales exposure over time through store consolidation?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question, Matt, and one that we think about a lot. Overall, in retail, the key metric that we're focused on is gross margin dollar comp. And to that end, it's always that interplay between sales and margin rate. I do believe that in retail, w
componenttext: It's a great question, Matt, and one that we think about a lot. Overall, in retail, the key metric that we're focused on is gross margin dollar comp. And to that end, it's always that interplay between sales and margin rate. I do believe that in retail, we need to be competitive on KPIs. So, for example, right now during back-to-school, the key KPIs is our less list, that's a multiple, and we are very competitive on them. On the other hand, retail does have a different cost structure and has convenience aspects that you don't have online. So I don't foresee us pegging our retail pricing to the online competition.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, and then my second question Christine mentioned M&A is something you're looking at in the commercial arena. What's your prospective deals look like? Are they all beyond office supply area? Are they all mid-market? Are these bolt-on deals? Is there
componenttext: Got it, and then my second question Christine mentioned M&A is something you're looking at in the commercial arena. What's your prospective deals look like? Are they all beyond office supply area? Are they all mid-market? Are these bolt-on deals? Is there anything at all potentially transformational or really material that we might see pop up over the next year?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as we think about driving growth in mid-market, which is our key growth lever going forward, there's a couple different flavors of M&A. Clearly, as I said earlier, the tuck-ins are just a clear win. They're accretive. They're easy to integrate, and we
componenttext: So as we think about driving growth in mid-market, which is our key growth lever going forward, there's a couple different flavors of M&A. Clearly, as I said earlier, the tuck-ins are just a clear win. They're accretive. They're easy to integrate, and we are well underway there. We also are thinking about how we expand within mid-market, and that could lead us to kind of a different group of M&A, but there's no specific decisions or direction on that at this time.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would that -- not to push too hard on this, would that be different based on a category? Would it be different based on geography? Would it be different based on sort of selling techniques field versus online versus phone, et cetera?
componenttext: And would that -- not to push too hard on this, would that be different based on a category? Would it be different based on geography? Would it be different based on sort of selling techniques field versus online versus phone, et cetera?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look at our overall 4 strategic priorities, it's going to be in North America because that's where we're focused. It's probably being more delivery oriented because that's our future, and it's more likely not to be the dealers really
componenttext: Well, I think if you look at our overall 4 strategic priorities, it's going to be in North America because that's where we're focused. It's probably being more delivery oriented because that's our future, and it's more likely not to be the dealers really add scale to more of the core. So it's more likely to be in categories beyond the core.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brad Thomas with KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brad Thomas with KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Shira, wanted to follow up on the topic of growth in the mid-markets, and there was an earlier question about competition, but can you talk a little bit more about what the competitive landscape looks like for those customers of yours with 10 to 200
componenttext: Yes. Shira, wanted to follow up on the topic of growth in the mid-markets, and there was an earlier question about competition, but can you talk a little bit more about what the competitive landscape looks like for those customers of yours with 10 to 200 employees? And perhaps what level of competition you're seeing out of an Amazon in that segment today?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's a very broad competitive set. It's everything from dealers to Office Depot to online players to warehouse clubs, et cetera. And in developing our value proposition mid-market, we've thought very carefully how do we win against each one of the
componenttext: Yes, so it's a very broad competitive set. It's everything from dealers to Office Depot to online players to warehouse clubs, et cetera. And in developing our value proposition mid-market, we've thought very carefully how do we win against each one of the different competitors. So how do we play something. So it's -- our goal is to be -- our antes are deep assortment, competitive pricing and very reliable and flexible delivery, and that enables us to compete against one set of competitors. So as an example: the delivery is a plus versus the warehouse clubs but, on the other hand, what's critical and what's really our differentiator is expertise and services, and that enables us to compete against a different set of competitors. The other thing I would say about mid-market, which I think we're somewhat unique in this space is it is the combination of the what I'd call the online and the offline that really gives us a unique and highly valued by customer offering. So we leverage our E-Commerce and digital capabilities that most folks are more familiar with through our public websites, but we have it on our private website. We've used the digital marketing, digital selling aids, but we also have the personal connection, whether it's literally in person in someone's office or be it telesales. So we've really crafted it, looking at all the different competitors and seeing how can we gain share no matter who is the competitor when we enter an office.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Lasser with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Lasser with UBS.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was helpful that you provided the cash contribution to the retail business is going to offer to the total business this year. Can you elaborate on the overall financial benefit of the retail business to the contract business? Just a few years ago, you'
componenttext: It was helpful that you provided the cash contribution to the retail business is going to offer to the total business this year. Can you elaborate on the overall financial benefit of the retail business to the contract business? Just a few years ago, you're generating about $1 billion of operating profit in the North American Stores and Online segment. That's probably going to be closer to $350 million to $400 million this year. So at the rate it's going, those financial benefits are going to quickly evaporate, and it will be helpful to understand how that's going to impact the overall business or particularly the contract business.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so there is a nice tie in between stores and mid-market, but I wouldn't say it is a critical linkage. The 2 critical -- the 2 nice tie ins is the vast majority of businesses experience Staples through our stores and online business. That's where we h
componenttext: Yes, so there is a nice tie in between stores and mid-market, but I wouldn't say it is a critical linkage. The 2 critical -- the 2 nice tie ins is the vast majority of businesses experience Staples through our stores and online business. That's where we have the 2 million visits today, and we've increasingly finding that by mining those customers who knows Staples and who likes Staples and by digitally qualifying them, we can then migrate them to our Staples Business Advantage, so that is a nice linkage. We also do have buy online and pickup in store for our contract customers, and we also have a print a store for our contract customers and those are nice benefits, but I wouldn't say they're particularly meaningful in scale at this time.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: What about purchasing benefit? How much of your gross margin for your contracted business is supported by the fact that you're buying as a larger organization?
componenttext: What about purchasing benefit? How much of your gross margin for your contracted business is supported by the fact that you're buying as a larger organization?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That we don't have exact quantification on. Obviously, there are purchasing synergies because of our overall scale but regardless, definitely in the quarter, we're going to be one of the largest buyers in the office supply area regardless of what happens.
componenttext: That we don't have exact quantification on. Obviously, there are purchasing synergies because of our overall scale but regardless, definitely in the quarter, we're going to be one of the largest buyers in the office supply area regardless of what happens. So that's not something that right now I'm losing a lot of sleep over.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It seems right now the strategy is you continue to close stores at a measured pace opportunistically when the leases come off for renewal. Is there a way to more quickly marginalize or isolate any potential or the potential drag on the overall business th
componenttext: It seems right now the strategy is you continue to close stores at a measured pace opportunistically when the leases come off for renewal. Is there a way to more quickly marginalize or isolate any potential or the potential drag on the overall business that your retail segment is contributing?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think it's multitier. First of all, I think we just can and need to operate our retail business better, and I think we have a line of sight to doing that. Part of that is being very clear that the strategy is preserving profitability, focused on gros
componenttext: So I think it's multitier. First of all, I think we just can and need to operate our retail business better, and I think we have a line of sight to doing that. Part of that is being very clear that the strategy is preserving profitability, focused on gross margin dollars versus chasing after profitless sales. The example I just gave you about computers, I think, is a good example of how we've pivoted in that area. I think the second piece is taking a hard look at our fixed costs outside of the leases but just the other fixed cost that we have to support retail, and then as you said, just looking very critically at our store network as the leases come up.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a big-picture question with a few parts to it. As you think about your strategic plan, how is it being affected by Office Depot strategic plans? So, for example, is the European sale affected by Office Depot looking to do the same? Do you slow North
componenttext: It's a big-picture question with a few parts to it. As you think about your strategic plan, how is it being affected by Office Depot strategic plans? So, for example, is the European sale affected by Office Depot looking to do the same? Do you slow North American store closings and wait for them to lead on that? They seem to be moving faster than you in that regard. Do you see them being more aggressive in pricing in the contract business? And lastly, do you have any interest in building out your international business outside of Europe? You have an Australian business. You bought Corporate Express in Australia. They have a business, I believe, in Australia. Is that a possibility as well?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me take the last question first. I think as I stated in the strategy, our go-forward thinking really is focused on North America. So there really isn't a lot of plans to build out internationally more. And regarding the rest of it is listen, do we
componenttext: So let me take the last question first. I think as I stated in the strategy, our go-forward thinking really is focused on North America. So there really isn't a lot of plans to build out internationally more. And regarding the rest of it is listen, do we look at all of our competitors? Absolutely, but I think we're also in a position that we play to our game, and we're very, very focused on our customers and what it's going to take to both win them and then grow them and keep them, and that's what consumes our conversations here. On store closures yes, obviously. When you're looking at stores, you're looking at the network and what's proximate and what's likely to close and what's not likely to close, and we have a great real estate team, and they take all that into account as we're making the store-by-store decision. But I also think that when you look at the strategies of the 2 companies, they are somewhat different at this point. I mean, we really are focusing on mid-market. We have a track record there. We're building our momentum. We're building on an offering that's already gaining share, and we're building on very profitable part of our business. So we've kind of said that's where we're going to double down. I don't sit in competitor boardrooms, but the feeling I got was their strategy was a lot more about continuing to double down on stores, and our strategy there is to preserve profitability.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in contract, as you mentioned, there's been gaps in terms of the performance, and they complained about the need -- people not signing up with them or looking to them because of the pending acquisition, but now do you see them coming out and swinging o
componenttext: So in contract, as you mentioned, there's been gaps in terms of the performance, and they complained about the need -- people not signing up with them or looking to them because of the pending acquisition, but now do you see them coming out and swinging on pricing to try to regain momentum in customer acquisition?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Joe's going on this one. I'll ask him to respond.
componenttext: So Joe's going on this one. I'll ask him to respond.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's fair one to say that they continue to be aggressive. So there's not any heightened sense of aggressiveness out there. That being said, many of the larger customers of ours certainly have not been going out to bid during the interim time
componenttext: Yes, I think it's fair one to say that they continue to be aggressive. So there's not any heightened sense of aggressiveness out there. That being said, many of the larger customers of ours certainly have not been going out to bid during the interim time period here over the last 12 to 18 months, and so there is some pent-up demand there. So there will be more bids that will become available into the marketplace on renewals, et cetera, on both sides. And I think that's increased activity out there, and we'll see where it goes, but I think it will continue to be competitive as it has been in the past.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, and just a last question is the mid-single-digit decline in ink and toner that you talked about, how does that compare to prior quarters? And just curious if you see that as an indication of sort of an accelerating structural headwind or on di
componenttext: Understood, and just a last question is the mid-single-digit decline in ink and toner that you talked about, how does that compare to prior quarters? And just curious if you see that as an indication of sort of an accelerating structural headwind or on digital or something going on in the economic environment?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Chris, it is likely accelerated from prior quarters, and we are getting our arms around it, how much of it is Staples and how much of it is the industry. But again, from my perspective, it just puts the heightened urgency around the transformation and
componenttext: So Chris, it is likely accelerated from prior quarters, and we are getting our arms around it, how much of it is Staples and how much of it is the industry. But again, from my perspective, it just puts the heightened urgency around the transformation and the focus on our beyond office supply category, and that is where we're putting a lot of the resources to grow, and that's where it's paying off. So with that, the magical hour of 11:00, and it was a little bit of a late call to start today. So in closing, thank you all for joining us. Kevin, thank you for moderating, and most of all, I'd like to thank all of our associates around the world, who've been working with tremendous commitment and energy to transform Staples. It's really their focus on our customers and their passion to win that makes me most optimistic about our future. Thanks for joining us today, and have a great day.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's presentation. You may now disconnect, and have a wonderful day.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this does conclude today's presentation. You may now disconnect, and have a wonderful day.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Staples Inc. Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference call, Mr. Chris Power
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Staples Inc. Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference call, Mr. Chris Powers. You may begin, sir.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kevin. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us for our second quarter 2016 earnings call. During today's call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP metrics. Please see the financial measures and the other data section of the Investor Informa
componenttext:
Thanks, Kevin. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us for our second quarter 2016 earnings call. During today's call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP metrics. Please see the financial measures and the other data section of the Investor Information portion of staples.com for a reconciliation of these measures. Certain information we will discuss constitutes forward-looking statements for purposes of the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by such forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including those discussed or referenced in Staples 10-Q filed this morning. 
Here to discuss Staples Q2 performance and outlook are Shira Goodman, interim Chief Executive Officer; and Christine Komola, Chief Financial Officer.
Also joining us are Joe Doody, Vice Chairman, North American Operations; and John Wilson, President, International Operations and Head of Global Transformation.
Shira?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. This morning, we announced Q2 results that were right in line with our expectation. I'd like to start by thanking the entire Staples team for remaining focused and delivering solid re
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. This morning, we announced Q2 results that were right in line with our expectation. I'd like to start by thanking the entire Staples team for remaining focused and delivering solid results during quite an eventful quarter that included the termination of our proposed acquisition of Office Depot, the immediate launch of a new strategic plan and a change in leadership. 
Total company sales were down less than 2%, excluding the impact of store closures, changes in foreign exchange rates and the divestiture of our contract print business. Non-GAAP operating income grew 2% year-over-year, and non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.12 was flat versus Q2 of last year despite a slightly higher effective tax rate and share count. 
But before I discuss Q2 results in more detail, I'd like to just take a few minutes to provide some color on my first 2 months in the new role. 
I take on this role with a great sense of urgency. When I joined Staples in 1992, we were in the process of creating our catalog business. And over the years, I've seen it grow organically and through acquisitions. At that time, we had only 174 stores, and we were still 6 years away from launching staples.com. 
So it goes without saying that a lot has changed over the past 24 years as Staples has evolved from a retail company with a fledgling delivery business to a delivery company with a retail business. And yet, for all the change that I've been part of, the most important thing about our company has remained constant--our commitment to our business customers and to transforming to meet their changing needs. 
So June 15 was my first day on the job, and I dove right in. My top priority is to position our company for sustainable, long-term sales and earnings growth. And we're doing that via our Staples 2020 strategy.  This strategy includes a dramatic change in our mindset and our operating model. We're doubling down on Staples Business Advantage, our North American contract business, where we have solid momentum on both the top and bottom line as well as a best-in-class offering to build on. At the same time, we're focusing on maximizing profitability and reducing risk in our underperforming retail and European businesses. 
I'm confident that our future is bright, and the reason I'm so confident is because our strengths so far outnumber our challenges. We have what we need to win. 
Nearly 2 million customers visit our websites and our stores everyday. We have a world-class distribution network that provides next-day delivery to business customers of all sizes. Half of our sales now come from categories beyond office supplies, and we have expertise in these adjacent categories that allows us to expand our share of wallet with customers. 
Well over half of our sales are generated online through our private and public websites. We have leading e-commerce and digital capabilities. Our brand is widely known and well-respected. Our balance sheet is strong and we have ample liquidity to support our long-term growth priorities. And most importantly, we have an incredible team of engaged and committed associates. 
On May 11, we announced our Staples 2020 strategy, which builds on all the strengths which I just listed but also address our biggest challenges. We have 4 critical strategic priorities: First, we're focused on winning in the mid-market in North America. I've spent a lot of time on this business over the years, and I couldn't be more optimistic about this opportunity. Second, preserving profitability in our North American stores. Third, taking aggressive action to further reduce costs and drive efficiency across the organization. And fourth, narrowing our geographic focus to North America by exploring strategic alternatives for our European operations. 
Now since launching Staples 2020, I've made some changes to our leadership team and our organizational structure to get the right talent in the right seats on the box. Joe Doody, our Vice Chairman, has assumed leadership for North American operations. You all know Joe. He's an 18-year Staples veteran, and he has been the key architect for building and leading high-performing teams across our North American delivery businesses for the majority of his time with the company. In his new role, Joe will focus on executing our Staples 2020 strategy, delivering on our 2016 financial goals and driving synergies and teamwork across our North American operations leadership team. 
During Q2, we also took an important step forward by more closely aligning staples.com and Staples Business Advantage under Neil Ringel, our Executive Vice President of Staples Business Advantage. Neil has been with Staples for 21 years, and for the last 5 years, has been leading our $7 billion North American contract organization and driving consistent growth. He is one of our most dynamic and capable leaders, and I'm excited about his expanded role. Also this improved alignment between SBA and dotcom will allow us to better serve our mid-market customers regardless of their ordering platform. 
As I mentioned a couple of minutes ago, we're focused on preserving profitability in our North American retail stores. Steve Matyas has been appointed President of North American Retail. Steve has over 25 years of experience at Staples, primarily leading our Canadian retail and online businesses. In his new role, Steve will also lead our U.S. retail business. His track record of delivering strong returns is well known across Staples. 
Finally, as we shared during Q1, John Wilson has taken on the additional responsibilities of driving our transformation for all of Staples, and he has been a real partner to me in doing so. 
And as our strategy evolves, I will continue making the changes necessary to put us in the best possible position to win. To that end, during Q2, we also held a company-wide leadership meeting to align the organization and make sure that each and every one of our leaders understood our new strategy and what was their role in making it happen. We've been adopting a transformation mindset, and I've been challenging the management team to lead with focus and accountability, speed and teamwork, what I call FAST, and have been delighted by the response and already visible changes in behavior. 
Now let me give you more color around the progress we've made on each of our Staples 2020 strategic priorities during Q2. Let's start with our top growth priority, winning in the mid-market in North America. 
We have a differentiated approach to serving mid-market customers where technology and innovation are at the core of our offering. This approach combines the personal touch of our sales force with digital selling tools and robust data on customer behavior and preferences.  Just to be clear, we define the mid-market as business customers with 10 to 200 employees, and they are a sweet spot for us. These customers are often large enough that they have sophisticated needs, but too small to have the expertise or resources for all of their needs in-house. Historically, our key differentiators in the mid-market have been deep assortment, very competitive pricing and fast delivery. Today, these differentiators have become table stakes. To win, we need to do more.  So we are accelerating our mid-market growth by leveraging our expertise and evolving our approach to customer acquisition, and we made some nice progress here during Q2. Mid-market sales grew in the mid-single digits versus last year, and this was fueled by double-digit growth in categories beyond office supplies as well as strong customer acquisition. We've enhanced our digital marketing and sales support capabilities, and by doing so, we are shortening the customer acquisition process and can significantly reduce the cost of acquisition. We also plan to double our mid-market sales force over the next few years and year-to-date, have already added over 100 mid-market sales reps, bringing our total to about 1,300 of mid-market sales headcount. 
Now we're not only modifying how we acquire customers, but we're also enhancing what we offer them. A growing percentage of our mid-market customers are taking advantage of our membership programs. These programs provide customized discounts and differentiated levels of service. The results are very encouraging, and we're seeing increased spend and loyalty from tens of thousands of businesses who have signed up for our membership program so far. 
And additionally, we're planning to utilize M&A as a growth catalyst. We've restarted our process of pursuing acquisitions to accelerate our mid-market strategy, and we're actively managing a strong pipeline of opportunities. 
Moving on to North American stores. Here, our top priority is to preserve profitability. Let me take a minute to give you some color on how we're managing the retail business. 
While our stores provide business customers with a level of service and convenience that differentiates Staples from the competition, I do want to be clear that we're not positioning our retail business as a key driver of long-term sales and earnings growth. That said, our stores generate a significant amount of free cash flow, and this cash is critical as we invest to reposition Staples by accelerating growth in mid-market and categories beyond office supplies. 
This year, our stores in North America are on track to generate over $200 million of free cash flow, which we're taking aggressive actions to preserve despite weak traffic. Our team is driving increased customer conversion, growing our high-margin copy and print and text service sets; evolving our promotional strategies; optimizing our marketing spend; focusing on reducing fixed costs, in line with sales decline; driving double-digit growth in key omni-channel capabilities like buy online and pickup in store; and we're achieving record level of customer service. 
But at the same time, we know we need to respond to changing customer behavior by continuing to reduce our retail footprint. Over the past 3 years, we've closed more than 300 stores in North America, and we're on track to close at least 50 stores this year. And over the next 3 years, an average of 225 store leases will expire per year in North America. This gives us tremendous flexibility to continue rightsizing our store network as appropriate without incurring significant cash costs. 
Our third strategic priority is cost reduction. As you know, over the past 3 years, we've eliminated $750 million of annualized pretax costs. And while we've made great progress taking out costs, I know we can continue to do things better, faster and cheaper. To that end, I've asked our teams to challenge the way we work and not be afraid to take on calculated risks to achieve our savings goals. We've initiated a new multiyear cost savings plan, which is expected to generate an additional $300 million of annualized pretax cost savings by 2018. 
I'm excited about this work. Our biggest opportunities are reducing product costs, increasing our mix of higher margin Staples brand products, driving productivity in our supply chain and evolving our promotional strategies. Many of these new savings initiatives are already underway, and we are on track to achieve approximately $70 million of annualized pretax cost savings during 2016. 
Finally, I'm pleased to report that we're progressing with our process to explore strategic alternatives for our European operation. John Wilson and his team have done a good job restructuring and streamlining Europe over the past few years, and this has positioned us very well.  We've seen a strong level of interest. And during Q2, our European management team met with a number of prospective buyers. We're currently working through due diligence, and we'll provide further details as the process continues. 
So to sum up, at Staples, we're in the early innings of a dynamic and pronounced strategic repositioning. We're moving from a product focus to a customer focus. We're moving from a retail culture to a delivery culture. We're evolving from a high-low pricing strategy to more everyday value. We're transitioning from a products company to a products and services company. We're utilizing M&A as a catalyst to augment our capabilities and drive growth, and we're narrowing our geographic footprint as we move from a broad international reach to a more pronounced focus on North America.  
And over the coming years, as we execute 2020, we will dramatically change the profile of our company. More than 95% of our sales will come from North America. More than 80% of our sales will be delivered, and more than 60% of our sales will come from categories beyond office supplies. 
So with that context, now let's take a quick look at Q2 results for each of our business units. Let's start with North America Commercial. Sales were up 1% year-over-year, excluding the negative impact of foreign exchange rates and the sale of Staples Print Solutions business. On a GAAP basis, sales in U.S. dollars were flat versus last year at $2 billion.  In Staples Business Advantage, our North American contract business, Q2 sales grew 3% in local currency after excluding the headwind from the Staples Print Solutions sale. We continued to drive strong growth in categories beyond office supplies. Sales were up in the double digits in facility supplies, promotional products and breakroom supplies. We also drove mid-single-digit sales growth in technology. 
Staples Business Advantage sales in core categories like ink and toner were down in the mid-single digits, and sales of paper and office supplies declined in the low single digits. 
During Q2, North American Commercial operating income rate increased 40 basis points to 7.1%, and operating income grew by $8 million or about 6% compared to last year. This improvement primarily reflects lower labor costs, partially offset by lower product margin rates. We also closed on the sale of our noncore Staples Print Solutions in early January. And just as a reminder, we're planning for about a 4% headwind to our reported North American Commercial sales and about a 2% headwind to our reported total company sales until we anniversary this sale during Q2 of next year. 
Turning to North America Stores and Online. Sales declined approximately 4%, excluding the negative impact of foreign exchange rates and store closures. On a GAAP basis, sales declined 6% to $2 billion. During Q2, combined North American Stores and Online comparable sales declined by 4%. This reflects 1% local currency sales growth in Staples.com and a 5% decline in same-store sales, primarily driven by a decline in customer traffic. 
Results in Canada were stronger than the U.S. in both stores and online. 
From a category perspective, the 4% decline in comparable sales during Q2 was almost entirely driven by ongoing weakness in tech categories like business machines and tech accessories, as well as ink and toner. These were all down in the mid to high single digits. For the rest of our categories, comparable sales in stores and online were down in the low single digit. 
North American Stores and Online operating income decreased 73 basis points to 0.6%. This reflects the negative impact of lower sales on fixed expenses in our stores, partially offset by improved profitability in Staples.com. 
We continued to rightsize our retail store network in North America, closing 19 stores in the U.S. during the first half of 2016. And I must note that the all-important back-to-school season is upon us with 
[Audio Gap]
or pick them up in store. We're also providing customers with the peace of mind that they're getting great value through our LESS List pricing and 110% lowest price guarantee. 
Finally, turning to International Operations. Sales decreased 4%, excluding the negative impact of changes in foreign exchange rates.  On a GAAP basis, sales in U.S. dollars were down 7% year-over-year to $721 million versus last year. In Europe, sales remained soft and were down in the low double digits in local currency. Outside of Europe, our strongest results were in China, where sales were up in the strong double digits year-over-year. 
On the bottom line, operating income rate for International Operations increased 91 basis points to an operating loss of 1.9%. The team in Europe once again did a nice job managing expenses and drove the majority of our reduced International losses year-over-year. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Christine to review our Q2 financial results and outlook in more detail.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Shira, and let me start off by providing a little bit more detail on our Q2 results. Total company sales for the second quarter were $4.8 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, total company sales declined less than 2% versus Q2 of last year. This excludes
componenttext:
Thanks, Shira, and let me start off by providing a little bit more detail on our Q2 results. Total company sales for the second quarter were $4.8 billion. On a non-GAAP basis, total company sales declined less than 2% versus Q2 of last year. This excludes a 1% headwind from changes in foreign exchange rates and a 1% headwind from the combination of store closures in North America and the sale of our Staples Print Solutions business during the second quarter. On a GAAP basis, sales declined 4% versus Q2 of last year. 
During the second quarter, we achieved non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.12, which was steady versus Q2 of last year. Our Q2 2016 non-GAAP diluted earnings per share excludes pretax charges of $986 million, primarily related to the impairment of goodwill and other assets and costs associated with the termination of the Office Depot merger.  On a GAAP basis, we reported net loss of $1.18 per share. 
During Q2, gross profit dollars decreased $67 million versus Q2 of last year, excluding a $4 million charge in Q2 of this year related to our decision to exit certain lines of business in our U.S. retail stores in connection with our strategic priority to preserve profitability. 
Non-GAAP gross profit rate for the second quarter decreased 43 basis points year-over-year to 25.2%. This primarily reflects lower product margin rate in North America Commercial and International Operations, as well as the negative impact of lower sales on fixed expenses like rent and occupancy in our retail stores. 
On a GAAP basis, gross profit rate decreased 52 basis points to 25.1% versus Q2 of last year. 
Turning to selling, general and administrative expense.
