During Q2, total company SG&A decreased $67 million year-over-year after excluding $24 million of charges in Q2 of this year, primarily related to litigation, as well as $10 million of charges primarily related to the proposed acquisition of Office Depot during Q2 of last year. Non-GAAP SG&A rate declined 53 basis points year-over-year to 22.2%. This reflects lower labor costs due to headcount reduction and store closures and lower marketing expense. 
On a GAAP basis, SG&A rate decreased 25 basis points to 22.7% versus Q2 of last year. Excluding the impact of charges, non-GAAP total company operating margin rate increased 14 basis points year-over-year to 2.7%. 
Now turning to our Q2 tax rate. Excluding the impact of charges, our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 35.5% versus our non-GAAP effective tax rate of 33.5% in Q2 of 2015. This year-over-year increase in our effective tax rate was primarily driven by changes in our geographic mix of earnings versus 2015. 
Turning to cash flow. Year-to-date capital expenditures came in at $102 million, a decrease of $36 million versus the prior year. With operating cash outflow of $11 million, our year-to-date free cash flow was an outflow of $113 million as of the end of the second quarter. Keep in mind that the breakup fee we paid to Office Depot as a result of the termination of the merger agreement was a $250 million operating cash outflow during the second quarter. We also made cash payments of about $90 million related to the Office Depot acquisition financing, which resulted in cash operating outflow during the first half of the year. These payments are tax deductible, and we do expect to realize the majority of the associated tax benefits in 2016. 
At the end of Q2, Staples had approximately $1.7 billion in liquidity, including cash and cash equivalents of $775 million and available lines of credit of about $889 million. 
We remain committed to returning excess cash to shareholders. We currently returned more than $300 million to shareholders annually for our cash dividend, and we are also balancing cash deployment through our share repurchases with our strong pipeline of M&A opportunities. 
When we announced our first quarter results, we were planning for share repurchases of approximately $100 million in 2016. But given the strength and the attractiveness of our tuck-in M&A opportunities, we chose to forgo purchasing shares during the second quarter and preserve our dry powder. 
Turning to our outlook. We remain on track to get back to earnings growth in 2016. During the third quarter of 2016, we expect total company sales to decline versus Q3 of last year. We expect to drive growth in categories beyond office supplies and in our contract businesses in North America. This will be offset by headwinds related to the sale of the Staples Print Solutions business, as well as ongoing weakness in Europe, continued technology headwinds in our retail stores and store closures. 
On the bottom line, we expect third quarter fully diluted non-GAAP earnings per share in the range of $0.32 to $0.35. Our earnings guidance excludes potential charges related to the company's strategic plans, including restructuring and related initiatives, as well as the ongoing of strategic alternatives for the company's European operations. 
We remain on track to generate approximately $600 million of free cash flow in 2016. Our free cash flow guidance excludes the after-tax impact to operating cash flow of approximately $340 million of charges associated with financing for the proposed acquisition of Office Depot and costs associated with the termination of the Office Depot merger agreement. 
As Shira mentioned, at the beginning of the call, we are positioning the company for sustainable, long-term sales and earnings growth as we execute our 2020 strategy. 
I'll now turn it back over to our conference call moderator, Kevin, for Q&A.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Greg Melich with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Greg Melich with Evercore ISI.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'd love to think back a little bit over the last year, especially given what your former merger partner was saying about how they had lost some business, yet if we look at your own commercial sales, they've also slowed. So I'm just trying to put
componenttext: I guess, I'd love to think back a little bit over the last year, especially given what your former merger partner was saying about how they had lost some business, yet if we look at your own commercial sales, they've also slowed. So I'm just trying to put those 2 things together. Is it just the market is slower? And then the second question, I had a follow-up on the retail side.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Greg. In fact, our Staples Business Advantage contract business has had steady to accelerating growth. And we do look at the gap between ourselves and Office Depot, and for probably 8 quarters now, it's been consistently in the 600 to 800 basis poin
componenttext: Okay, Greg. In fact, our Staples Business Advantage contract business has had steady to accelerating growth. And we do look at the gap between ourselves and Office Depot, and for probably 8 quarters now, it's been consistently in the 600 to 800 basis points. And this last quarter, it widened closer to 1,000 basis points. So we feel really good about our growth in Staples Business Advantage. It's driven by BOS, beyond office supplies sales, as well as customer acquisition. And just one kind of fun factoid in this season of the Olympics, one of our beyond office supplies categories was promotional products, and there's about 20 million pieces of flags, T-shirts, water bottles, et cetera, currently at the Olympics that was produced and provided by Staples promotional products. So things like that are really driving growth from that side of the house.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I misspoke. What I meant to say was not just the contract side, where you have seen it, but on the retail side, where your comp is down, say, 4 or 5, and I think theirs was, I can't remember exactly, I think it was down 1. How can that  success t
componenttext: I guess, I misspoke. What I meant to say was not just the contract side, where you have seen it, but on the retail side, where your comp is down, say, 4 or 5, and I think theirs was, I can't remember exactly, I think it was down 1. How can that  success translate over into the retail side?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So I think there's 2 things happening there. One is that Office Depot has gotten a lot more benefit from their store closures. They've done more in the past year. And because they were closing competitor stores, they were much more proximate and th
componenttext: Right. So I think there's 2 things happening there. One is that Office Depot has gotten a lot more benefit from their store closures. They've done more in the past year. And because they were closing competitor stores, they were much more proximate and therefore, a higher transfer rate, versus we were closing all of our own stores. So that accounts for about half of the gap. And I would say regarding the rest, well, our 2-year stacked comp actually improved from Q1 to Q2. So from a minus 9 to a minus 8. I think we at Staples all feel that we can and we'll do better on retail. We have many initiatives underway. The team is already doing well with conversion and market basket and customer satisfaction, but we believe that there's -- that we can do even better. And as I mentioned in my script, Steve Matyas is now leading that organization and is taking a fresh look at it, as well as transferring a lot of our learnings from Canada.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then the second follow-up was on the profitability of the retail business. I guess, it follows on that. The margin down to 0.6%. Was it gross margin? Was it SG&A? Was there anything in particular there to highlight? Categories that may have be
componenttext: Got it. And then the second follow-up was on the profitability of the retail business. I guess, it follows on that. The margin down to 0.6%. Was it gross margin? Was it SG&A? Was there anything in particular there to highlight? Categories that may have been driving that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll ask Christine to take that.
componenttext: So I'll ask Christine to take that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, basically, on the profitability side, the biggest driver was sales causing deleverage on some of the fixed costs during the quarter. As you know, this is a small quarter for us until we kick off into back-to-school season. So I think primarily, gros
componenttext: Greg, basically, on the profitability side, the biggest driver was sales causing deleverage on some of the fixed costs during the quarter. As you know, this is a small quarter for us until we kick off into back-to-school season. So I think primarily, gross margin pressure from sales decline. The rest of the P&L in terms of managing expenses, the team's done a great job leveraging things like the labor lines and marketing expense where we need to.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Binder with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Binder with Jefferies.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a few questions for you. First, on consolidation in the industry. You've seen a lot of dealers either going away or being acquired. I realize that they may be smaller in size and perhaps not normally worth the time. But since some of your competitor
componenttext: I had a few questions for you. First, on consolidation in the industry. You've seen a lot of dealers either going away or being acquired. I realize that they may be smaller in size and perhaps not normally worth the time. But since some of your competitors are actually buying them, is this something that you would revisit as you talk about M&A?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do believe that is an opportunity for us. We call those tuck-ins. We actually have a history of doing them, and they're very accretive. We get a lot of immediate synergies, and the integration is fairly straightforward as well. So when we talk abo
componenttext: Yes, we do believe that is an opportunity for us. We call those tuck-ins. We actually have a history of doing them, and they're very accretive. We get a lot of immediate synergies, and the integration is fairly straightforward as well. So when we talk about our strong pipeline of M&A, a good part of it is in the dealer community.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: My second question was around the membership program that you spoke about in the contract space. I was wondering if you could just elaborate a little bit on that a bit and give us some color around how much -- how many sales dollars are in those programs
componenttext: My second question was around the membership program that you spoke about in the contract space. I was wondering if you could just elaborate a little bit on that a bit and give us some color around how much -- how many sales dollars are in those programs today, how fast they're growing, what the key attraction is.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll ask Joe to answer that.
componenttext: I'll ask Joe to answer that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dan. I won't give you all the information you're probably looking for, but to give you some idea here. It's a great program that we've used primarily in the acquisition area of our mid-market customers. It gives customers, one, the incentive to have
componenttext: Sure, Dan. I won't give you all the information you're probably looking for, but to give you some idea here. It's a great program that we've used primarily in the acquisition area of our mid-market customers. It gives customers, one, the incentive to have larger order sizes. It also gives them various discounts on key product areas, specifically price, ink and toner. It's a program that has shown early on its strength in terms of both retention and penetration within those mid-market customers. So we are very happy with the program and continuing to expand it, not only for new customer acquisition, but also with existing customers.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And my last question was regarding Europe. Your comments today, Shira, sound perhaps maybe a greater level of commitment in shedding these assets. I suspect you may be getting a little bit further along in that process. But my question really is ar
componenttext: Great. And my last question was regarding Europe. Your comments today, Shira, sound perhaps maybe a greater level of commitment in shedding these assets. I suspect you may be getting a little bit further along in that process. But my question really is around the ability to separate that business from a systems perspective. If you can give us a little color on the complexity of that. I think you were putting some new systems in there recently. And then when you think this might get done. Is it something that you can do within the next quarter, by the end of the year, next year?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll ask Christine just to talk a little bit about the process, and John will talk a little bit about the ability to separate systems, et cetera.
componenttext: So I'll ask Christine just to talk a little bit about the process, and John will talk a little bit about the ability to separate systems, et cetera.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we are working through the process in Europe specifically right now. As Shira outlined, we're talking to different buyers. Management's been -- local management's been involved in the process, and all is going well. You know how these things go,
componenttext: Sure. So we are working through the process in Europe specifically right now. As Shira outlined, we're talking to different buyers. Management's been -- local management's been involved in the process, and all is going well. You know how these things go, you can never precisely determine timelines and kind of what the end result's going to be. But we're working with our teams and working with different buyers, so we feel good about the process and the underlying people that we are speaking to. In terms of the systems, I will let John handle it. But from a corporate standpoint, most of the systems, as you know, Europe is -- from a U.S. perspective versus Europe, it's fairly independent. So there's always some overlap on these systems. But for the most part, the local teams have very different systems than the North America team, and therefore, kind of -- you never take systems lightly, but it's not a big overhang for us.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just as Christine said, the amount of overlap in our systems is actually fairly modest compared to many other organizations. Probably the most integrated system we have is our online system, and there, we're looking at a transfer service agreement th
componenttext: Yes, just as Christine said, the amount of overlap in our systems is actually fairly modest compared to many other organizations. Probably the most integrated system we have is our online system, and there, we're looking at a transfer service agreement that will allow us to replicate that system and move the source code over. That's probably the only significant system. The others are fairly straightforward, and we would not anticipate any significant issues of separating the 2 entities.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Simeon Gutman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shira, my first question. You mentioned the need or the attempt to strike the right balance of investments in retail to preserve the cash flow. I guess, looking back over the last several years, is there anything that could have been done different, the p
componenttext: Shira, my first question. You mentioned the need or the attempt to strike the right balance of investments in retail to preserve the cash flow. I guess, looking back over the last several years, is there anything that could have been done different, the pace of store closings? Curious if you have a different view on the ultimate number of stores. Does it make sense to put, I guess, money capital or expense back into them to help to -- I guess, to slow down the rate of that decline?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think what we've done to date has been a good balance. As we've shared, we don't have a lot of stores that lose money, and most are -- and those that we have had historically, we have closed to date. So what is left in our portfolio is stores that ar
componenttext: So I think what we've done to date has been a good balance. As we've shared, we don't have a lot of stores that lose money, and most are -- and those that we have had historically, we have closed to date. So what is left in our portfolio is stores that are primarily cash flow positive. So it is a very careful balance of it. Having said that, with leases coming up over the coming 3 years and close to 750 leases over the next 3 years, that does give us a degree of flexibility to really assess our store network and to what extent do we continue to focus and invest in it and to what extent do we even put more focus on our delivery business.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I noticed computers were mentioned. I forget if it was in the press release or the call. But is that due to something internal or external? Is it just the comparisons are easy, and there's some modest growth in the category?
componenttext: And I noticed computers were mentioned. I forget if it was in the press release or the call. But is that due to something internal or external? Is it just the comparisons are easy, and there's some modest growth in the category?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what I mentioned, Simeon, was tech, and actually, most of the downdraft in tech in this quarter was more business machines and tech accessories. Computers actually were a drag on us last year, and the team has done a really nice job of that this year.
componenttext: So what I mentioned, Simeon, was tech, and actually, most of the downdraft in tech in this quarter was more business machines and tech accessories. Computers actually were a drag on us last year, and the team has done a really nice job of that this year. They have changed the assortment to make it more micro business focused. They've worked on the inventory levels, and perhaps best of all, our store team has improved the market basket associated with computers by about 20% year-over-year. So the team has done a nice job of stemming that issue.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my last question on contract in North American Commercial. Do you -- are you starting to get a sense, even anecdotally, that you're bumping against newer players? I mean, Amazon included, in bidding with business contracts?
componenttext: And then my last question on contract in North American Commercial. Do you -- are you starting to get a sense, even anecdotally, that you're bumping against newer players? I mean, Amazon included, in bidding with business contracts?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So despite what the FTC is saying, North American Commercial has always been a very competitive market for us, and I would say the competitive intensity is pretty constant. Yes, we are seeing some Amazon out there, but a lot of the competition still is th
componenttext: So despite what the FTC is saying, North American Commercial has always been a very competitive market for us, and I would say the competitive intensity is pretty constant. Yes, we are seeing some Amazon out there, but a lot of the competition still is the local dealers, and we do have very significant, I think, competitive advantages over them.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question focuses on retail, specifically on pricing. As we've taken kind of a fresh look at pricing from time to time, it seems like there's still a pretty big gulf in a lot of higher velocity items between yourselves and your channel and some of the l
componenttext: My question focuses on retail, specifically on pricing. As we've taken kind of a fresh look at pricing from time to time, it seems like there's still a pretty big gulf in a lot of higher velocity items between yourselves and your channel and some of the lower-priced resources out there, particularly online. And as I look at your comps, are you where you want to be? Are you willing to invest in price at retail to stop the share bleed? Or do you feel like you'd rather have the gross margin structure that you have and manage down the sales exposure over time through store consolidation?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question, Matt, and one that we think about a lot. Overall in retail, the key metric that we're focused on is gross margin dollar comp. And to that end, it's always that interplay between sales and margin rate. I do believe that in retail,
componenttext: That's a great question, Matt, and one that we think about a lot. Overall in retail, the key metric that we're focused on is gross margin dollar comp. And to that end, it's always that interplay between sales and margin rate. I do believe that in retail, we need to be competitive on KVIs, So for example, right now, during back-to-school, the key KVIs are our Less List list, that's a mouthful, and we are very competitive on them. On the other hand, retail does have a different cost structure and has convenience aspects that you don't have online. So I don't foresee us pegging our retail pricing to the online competition.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, and then my second question, Christine mentioned M&A as something you're looking at in the commercial arena. What's your prospective deals look like? Are they all in the beyond office supplies area? Are they all mid-market? Are these bolt-on deals
componenttext: Got it, and then my second question, Christine mentioned M&A as something you're looking at in the commercial arena. What's your prospective deals look like? Are they all in the beyond office supplies area? Are they all mid-market? Are these bolt-on deals? Is there anything at all potentially transformational or really material that we might see pop up over the next year?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as we think about driving growth in mid-market, which is our key growth lever going forward, there's a couple different flavors of M&A. Clearly, as I said earlier, the tuck-ins are just a clear win. They're accretive, they're easy to integrate and we a
componenttext: So as we think about driving growth in mid-market, which is our key growth lever going forward, there's a couple different flavors of M&A. Clearly, as I said earlier, the tuck-ins are just a clear win. They're accretive, they're easy to integrate and we are well underway there. We also are thinking about how we expand within mid-market, and that could lead us to kind of a different group of M&A, but there's no specific decisions or direction on that at this time.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And would that -- not to push too hard on this, would that be different based on category? Would it be different based on geography? Would it be different based on sort of selling techniques,  field versus online versus phone, et cetera?
componenttext: And would that -- not to push too hard on this, would that be different based on category? Would it be different based on geography? Would it be different based on sort of selling techniques,  field versus online versus phone, et cetera?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look at our overall 4 strategic priorities, it's going to be in North America because that's where we're focused. It's probably going to be more delivery-oriented, because that's our future. And it's more likely not to be -- the deale
componenttext: Well, I think if you look at our overall 4 strategic priorities, it's going to be in North America because that's where we're focused. It's probably going to be more delivery-oriented, because that's our future. And it's more likely not to be -- the dealers really add scale to more of the core, so it's more likely to be in categories beyond the core.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brad Thomas with KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brad Thomas with KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shira, wanted to follow up on the topic of growth in the mid-markets, and there was an earlier question about competition, but could you talk a little bit more about what the competitive landscape looks like for those customers of yours with 10 to 200 emp
componenttext: Shira, wanted to follow up on the topic of growth in the mid-markets, and there was an earlier question about competition, but could you talk a little bit more about what the competitive landscape looks like for those customers of yours with 10 to 200 employees? And perhaps what level of competition you're seeing out of an Amazon in that segment today?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's a very broad competitive set. It's everything from dealers to Office Depot to online players to warehouse clubs, et cetera. And in developing our value proposition mid-market, we've thought very carefully how do we win against each one of the
componenttext: Yes, so it's a very broad competitive set. It's everything from dealers to Office Depot to online players to warehouse clubs, et cetera. And in developing our value proposition mid-market, we've thought very carefully how do we win against each one of the different competitors. So how do we play something. So it's -- our goal is to be -- our antes are deep assortment, competitive pricing and very reliable and flexible delivery, and that enables us to compete against one set of competitors. As an example, the delivery is a plus versus the warehouse clubs. But on the other hand, what's critical and what's really our differentiator is expertise and services, and that enables us to compete against a different set of competitors. The other thing I would say about mid-market, which I think we're somewhat unique in this space, is it is the combination of the what I call the online and the offline, that really gives us a unique and highly valued by customer offering. So we leverage our e-commerce and digital capabilities that most folks are more familiar with through our public websites, but we have it on our private website. We've used the digital marketing, digital selling aids, but we also have the personal connection, whether it's literally in person in someone's office or be it telesales. So we've really crafted it, looking at all the different competitors and saying, how can we gain share no matter who is the competitor when we enter an office?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Lasser with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Lasser with UBS.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shira, it was helpful that you provided the cash contribution to the retail business is going to offer to the total business this year. Can you elaborate on the overall financial benefit of the retail business to the contract business? Because just a few
componenttext: Shira, it was helpful that you provided the cash contribution to the retail business is going to offer to the total business this year. Can you elaborate on the overall financial benefit of the retail business to the contract business? Because just a few years ago, you were generating about $1 billion of operating profit from the North American Stores and Online segment. That's probably going to be closer to $350 million to $400 million this year. So at the rate it's going, those financial benefits are going to quickly evaporate and it will be helpful to understand how that's going to impact the overall business, or particularly the contract business.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there is a nice tie-in between stores and mid-market, but I wouldn't say it is a critical linkage. The 2 nice tie-ins is the vast majority of businesses experience Staples through our stores and online business, that's where we have the 2 million
componenttext: Yes. So there is a nice tie-in between stores and mid-market, but I wouldn't say it is a critical linkage. The 2 nice tie-ins is the vast majority of businesses experience Staples through our stores and online business, that's where we have the 2 million visits to date. And we're increasingly finding that by mining those customers who knows Staples and who likes Staples, and by digitally qualifying them, we can then migrate them to our Staples Business Advantage. So that is a nice linkage. We also do have buy online, pickup in store for our contract customers, and we also have a printer store for our contract customers, and those are nice benefits, but I wouldn't say they're particularly meaningful in scale at this time.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: What about purchasing benefit? How much of your gross margin for your contract is supported by the fact that you're buying as a larger organization?
componenttext: What about purchasing benefit? How much of your gross margin for your contract is supported by the fact that you're buying as a larger organization?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That, we don't have exact quantification on. Obviously, there are purchasing synergies because of our overall scale. But regardless, definitely in the quarter, we're going to be one of the largest buyers in the office supply area regardless of what happen
componenttext: That, we don't have exact quantification on. Obviously, there are purchasing synergies because of our overall scale. But regardless, definitely in the quarter, we're going to be one of the largest buyers in the office supply area regardless of what happens. So that's not something that, right now, I'm losing a lot of sleep over.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it seems like right now, the strategy is to continue to close stores at a measured pace opportunistically when the leases come off for renewal. Is there a way to more quickly marginalize or isolate any potential, or the potential drag on the overall bu
componenttext: So it seems like right now, the strategy is to continue to close stores at a measured pace opportunistically when the leases come off for renewal. Is there a way to more quickly marginalize or isolate any potential, or the potential drag on the overall business that your retail segment is contributing?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think it's multi-tier. First of all, I think we just can and need to operate our retail business better, and I think we have a line of sight to doing that. Part of that is being very clear that the strategy is preserving profitability, focused on gro
componenttext: So I think it's multi-tier. First of all, I think we just can and need to operate our retail business better, and I think we have a line of sight to doing that. Part of that is being very clear that the strategy is preserving profitability, focused on gross margin dollars versus chasing after profitless sales. The example I just gave to you about computers, I think, is a good example of how we've pivoted in that area. I think the second piece is taking a hard look at our fixed costs outside of the leases, but just the other fixed cost that we have to support retail. And then as you said, just looking very critically at our store network as the leases come up.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Christopher Horvers with JPMorgan.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a big-picture question with a few parts to it. As you think about your strategic plan, how is it being affected by Office Depot strategic plans? So for example, is the European sale affected by Office Depot looking to do the same? Do you slow North A
componenttext: It's a big-picture question with a few parts to it. As you think about your strategic plan, how is it being affected by Office Depot strategic plans? So for example, is the European sale affected by Office Depot looking to do the same? Do you slow North American store closings and wait for them to lead on that, and they seem to be moving faster than you in that regard? Do you see them being more aggressive in pricing in the contract business? And lastly, do you have any interest in building out your international business outside of Europe? You have an Australian business. You bought Corporate Express in Australia. They have a business, I believe, in Australia. Is that a possibility as well?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me take the last question first. I think as I stated in the strategy, our go-forward thinking really is focused on North America. So there really isn't a lot of plans to build out internationally more. And regarding the rest of it is, listen, do we
componenttext: So let me take the last question first. I think as I stated in the strategy, our go-forward thinking really is focused on North America. So there really isn't a lot of plans to build out internationally more. And regarding the rest of it is, listen, do we look at all of our competitors? Absolutely. But I think we're also in the position that we play to our game. And we're very, very focused on our customers and what it's going to take to both win them and then grow them and keep them, and that's what consumes our conversations here. On store closures yes, obviously, when you're looking at stores, you're looking at the network and what's proximate and what's likely to close and what's not likely to close. And we have a great real estate team, and they take all that into account as we're making the store-by-store decisions. But I also think that when you look at the strategies of the 2 companies, they are somewhat different at this point. I mean, we really are focusing on mid-market. We have a track record there. We're building our momentum. We're building on an offering that's already gaining share. And we're building on a very profitable part of our business. So we've kind of said that's where we're going to double down. I don't sit in competitor boardrooms, but the feeling I got was their strategy was a lot more about continuing to double down on stores, and our strategy there is to preserve profitability.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in contract, as you mentioned, there's been gaps in terms of the performance, and they complained about the need to -- people not signing up with them or looking to them because of the pending acquisition. But now, do you see them coming out and swingi
componenttext: So in contract, as you mentioned, there's been gaps in terms of the performance, and they complained about the need to -- people not signing up with them or looking to them because of the pending acquisition. But now, do you see them coming out and swinging on pricing to try to regain momentum in customer acquisition?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Joe's going in the trenches on this one. I'll ask him to respond.
componenttext: So Joe's going in the trenches on this one. I'll ask him to respond.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's fair, one, to say that they've continued to be aggressive. So there's not any heightened sense of aggressiveness out there. That being said, many of the larger customers of ours certainly have not been going out to bid during the interim
componenttext: Yes, I think it's fair, one, to say that they've continued to be aggressive. So there's not any heightened sense of aggressiveness out there. That being said, many of the larger customers of ours certainly have not been going out to bid during the interim time period here over the last 12 to 18 months, and so there is some pent-up demand there. So there will be more bids that will become available into the marketplace on renewals, et cetera on both sides. And I think that's increased activity out there, and we'll see where it goes. But I think it will continue to be competitive as it has been in the past.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just the last question is the mid-single-digit decline in ink and toner that you talked about, how does that compare to prior quarters? And just curious if you see that as an indication of sort of an accelerating structural headwind or on
componenttext: Understood. And just the last question is the mid-single-digit decline in ink and toner that you talked about, how does that compare to prior quarters? And just curious if you see that as an indication of sort of an accelerating structural headwind or on digital, or something going on in the economic environment?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Chris, it is likely accelerated from prior quarters, and we are getting our arms around it, how much of it is Staples and how much of it is the industry. But again, from my perspective, it just puts the heightened urgency around the transformation and
componenttext:
So Chris, it is likely accelerated from prior quarters, and we are getting our arms around it, how much of it is Staples and how much of it is the industry. But again, from my perspective, it just puts the heightened urgency around the transformation and the focus on our beyond office supplies category, and that is where we're putting a lot of the resources to grow, and that's where it's paying off. 
So with that, we've hit the magical hour of 11:00, and it was a little bit of a late call to start today. So in closing, thank you all for joining us. Kevin, thank you for moderating. And most of all, I'd like to thank all of our associates around the world who've been working with tremendous commitment and energy to transform Staples. It's really their focus on our customers and their passion to win that makes me most optimistic about our future. Thanks for joining us today, and have a great day.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 17, 2016
